Introduction

An optimization is a problem of the form

{minimize(f(x):x∈S)maximize(f(x):x∈S)\begin{cases} \textrm{minimize}(f(x):x\in S)\\ \textrm{maximize}(f(x):x\in S) \end{cases} {minimize(f(x):x∈S)maximize(f(x):x∈S)​

  • Feasible Region is set SSS
  • Objective Function: f:S→Rf:S\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:S→R

Note that min⁡(f(x):x∈S)=max⁡(−f(x):x∈S)\min(f(x):x\in S) =\max(-f(x) : x\in S)min(f(x):x∈S)=max(−f(x):x∈S)

  • Feasibility: we say that min⁡(f(x):x∈S)\min(f(x):x\in S)min(f(x):x∈S) is feasible if SSS is non-empty
  • Boundedness: we say that min⁡(f(x):x∈S)\min(f(x):x\in S)min(f(x):x∈S) is bounded if there exists b∈Rb\in\textrm{R}b∈R such that f(x)≥bf(x)\ge bf(x)≥b for each x∈Sx\in Sx∈S. This definition is analogues to the formal definition of big O notation.
  • Ill-Posedness: min⁡(x:x>1)\min(x:x>1)min(x:x>1) is both feasible and bounded, but there is no optimal solution.

Axiom (L1-1): if a set is non-empty and bounded below, then there exists a greatest lower bound

For minimization problems: if min⁡(f(x):x∈S)\min(f(x):x\in S)min(f(x):x∈S) is both feasible and bounded, then we can find an optimal bound

  • Infimum: inf⁡(f(x):x∈S)=max⁡(b∈R:b≤f(x) ∀ x∈S)\inf(f(x):x\in S)=\max(b\in \mathbb{R}:b\le f(x)\ \forall\ x\in S)inf(f(x):x∈S)=max(b∈R:b≤f(x) ∀ x∈S)

    inf⁡(f(x):x∈S)≔{∞if infeasible−∞if unbounded\displaystyle \inf(f(x):x\in S) \coloneqq \begin{cases} \infty & \textrm{if infeasible}\\-\infty &\textrm{if unbounded}\end{cases} inf(f(x):x∈S):={∞−∞​if infeasibleif unbounded​

  • Optimal Value: OPT(min⁡(f(x):x∈S))≔inf⁡(f(x):x∈S)\textrm{OPT}(\min(f(x):x\in S)) \coloneqq \inf(f(x):x\in S)OPT(min(f(x):x∈S)):=inf(f(x):x∈S)

For maximization problems: max⁡(f(x):x∈S)\max(f(x):x\in S)max(f(x):x∈S)

  • Supremum: sup⁡(f(x):x∈S)≔−inf⁡(−f(x):x∈S)\sup(f(x):x\in S)\coloneqq -\inf(-f(x) : x\in S)sup(f(x):x∈S):=−inf(−f(x):x∈S)
  • Optimal Value: OPT(max⁡(f(x):x∈S))≔sup⁡(f(x):x∈S)\textrm{OPT}(\max(f(x):x\in S))\coloneqq \sup(f(x):x\in S)OPT(max(f(x):x∈S)):=sup(f(x):x∈S)

Linear Optimization Problems Example: given a linear system Ax=bAx=bAx=b, where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm, find x∈Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn that is as close to feasible as possible with respect to the L1L^1L1 norm. (Fore more information, L1L^1L1-Norm, L2L^2L2-Norm, and L∞L^\inftyL∞-Norm. In 3D space, L1L^1L1 bound is octahedron, L2L^2L2 bound is sphere, and L∞L^\inftyL∞ bound is cube). We demonstrate the definitive non-linear formulation, and its linear counterpart:

Non-Linear Formulation Linear Formulation
min⁡(∑i=1m∣zi∣:{z=b−Axz∈Rm,x∈Rn)\displaystyle \min\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m} \vert z_i\vert : \begin{cases}z=b-Ax\\z\in \mathbb{R}^m,x\in \mathbb{R}^n\end{cases}\right)min(i=1∑m​∣zi​∣:{z=b−Axz∈Rm,x∈Rn​) min⁡(∑i=1mzi:{z≥b−Axz≥Ax−bz∈Rm,x∈Rn)\min\left(\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^m z_i :\begin{cases}z\ge b-Ax\\z\ge Ax-b\\z\in\mathbb{R}^m,x\in\mathbb{R}^n\end{cases}\right)min⎝⎜⎜⎛​i=1∑m​zi​:⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​z≥b−Axz≥Ax−bz∈Rm,x∈Rn​⎠⎟⎟⎞​

A couple important notes regarding these formulations:

  • The ∑i=1m∣zi∣\displaystyle \sum_{i=1}^m |z_i|i=1∑m​∣zi​∣ is non-linear because the norm heuristic is considered non-linear
  • The key idea of equivalent linear formulation is ∣a∣=min⁡(t∈R:t≥a,t≥−a)|a|=\min(t\in \mathbb{R}:t\ge a, t\ge -a)∣a∣=min(t∈R:t≥a,t≥−a)

Integer Linear Optimization Problems Example: weighted bipartite matching: given nnn jobs, nnn workers, and a utility aija_{ij}aij​ for worker iii performing job jjj, find an assignment of jobs to workers maximizing the total utility. We define variables xij∈0,1x_{ij}\in {0,1}xij​∈0,1, where xij=1x_{ij}=1xij​=1 when worker iii performs job jjj.

  • Integer Program Formulation: max⁡(∑i=1n∑j=1naijxij:∑i=1nxij=∑j=1nxij=1, xij≥0, xij∈Z ∀ i,j∈{1,…,n})\displaystyle \max \left(\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^na_{ij} x_{ij}:\sum_{i=1}^nx_{ij}=\sum_{j=1}^n x_{ij}=1,\ x_{ij}\ge 0,\ x_{ij}\in \mathbb{Z}\ \forall\ i,j\in \{ 1,\dots, n \}\right)max(i=1∑n​j=1∑n​aij​xij​:i=1∑n​xij​=j=1∑n​xij​=1, xij​≥0, xij​∈Z ∀ i,j∈{1,…,n})
  • Linear Relaxation: "relax" the integer constraint, and formulate the same problem as linear problem

    max⁡(∑i=1n∑j=1naijxij:∑i=1nxij=∑j=1nxij=1, xij≥0, ∀ i,j∈{1,…,n})\max \left(\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^na_{ij} x_{ij}:\sum_{i=1}^nx_{ij}=\sum_{j=1}^n x_{ij}=1,\ x_{ij}\ge 0,\ \forall\ i,j\in \{ 1,\dots, n \}\right) max(i=1∑n​j=1∑n​aij​xij​:i=1∑n​xij​=j=1∑n​xij​=1, xij​≥0, ∀ i,j∈{1,…,n})

Example: 3D Matching: given nnn jobs, nnn worker, nnn machines, and a utility of aijka_{ijk}aijk​ for worker i performing job jjj on machine kkk, find an assignment maximizing the total utility

  • IP Formulation: max⁡(∑i=1n∑j=1n∑k=1naijkxijk:∑i=1n∑j=1nxijk=∑i=1n∑k=1nxijk=∑j=1n∑k=1nxijk=1,xijk≥0,xijk∈Z ∀i,j,k∈{1,…,n})\displaystyle \max\left(\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n a_{ijk} x_{ijk}:\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^n x_{ijk}=\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n x_{ijk}=\sum_{j=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n x_{ijk}=1, x_{ijk}\ge 0, x_{ijk}\in\mathbb{Z}\ \forall i,j,k\in\{1,\dots,n\}\right)max(i=1∑n​j=1∑n​k=1∑n​aijk​xijk​:i=1∑n​j=1∑n​xijk​=i=1∑n​k=1∑n​xijk​=j=1∑n​k=1∑n​xijk​=1,xijk​≥0,xijk​∈Z ∀i,j,k∈{1,…,n})
  • Linear Relaxation: max⁡(∑i=1n∑j=1n∑k=1naijkxijk:∑i=1n∑j=1nxijk=∑i=1n∑k=1nxijk=∑j=1n∑k=1nxijk=1,xijk≥0 ∀i,j,k∈{1,…,n})\displaystyle \max\left(\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n a_{ijk} x_{ijk}:\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^n x_{ijk}=\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n x_{ijk}=\sum_{j=1}^n\sum_{k=1}^n x_{ijk}=1, x_{ijk}\ge 0\ \forall i,j,k\in\{1,\dots,n\}\right)max(i=1∑n​j=1∑n​k=1∑n​aijk​xijk​:i=1∑n​j=1∑n​xijk​=i=1∑n​k=1∑n​xijk​=j=1∑n​k=1∑n​xijk​=1,xijk​≥0 ∀i,j,k∈{1,…,n})

Claim (L1-2): OPT(LP)≥OPT(IP)\textrm{OPT}(LP)\ge \textrm{OPT}(IP)OPT(LP)≥OPT(IP), i.e. results from linear problem may be more optimized just because the integer constraint is relaxed.

Corollary (L1-3): Quadratic optimization problems are NP-hard.

Remark: x∈{0,1}x\in \{0,1\}x∈{0,1} if and only if x(x−1)=0x(x-1)=0x(x−1)=0. This will come in handy in the future.

Convex Sets and Cones

  • Convex Set: A set S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn is convex if for each x,y∈Sx,y\in Sx,y∈S, the line segment between x,yx,yx,y is contained in SSS. That is,

    λx+(1−λ)y∈S ∀x,y∈S,λ∈[0,1]\lambda x+ (1-\lambda)y\in S\ \forall x,y\in S, \lambda\in[0,1] λx+(1−λ)y∈S ∀x,y∈S,λ∈[0,1]

  • Convex Hull of set X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn, denoted conv(x)\textrm{conv}(x)conv(x), is the smallest convex set containing XXX.
  • Cones: A convex set containing 0 that is closed under non-negative scalar multiplication. In other words, A set of K⊆RnK\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nK⊆Rn is a cone if (1) KKK is convex, (2) 0∈K0\in K0∈K, and (3) ∀x∈K,λ≥0\forall x\in K,\lambda\ge 0∀x∈K,λ≥0, we have λ⋅x∈K\lambda\cdot x\in Kλ⋅x∈K.
  • Conical Hull cone(S)\textrm{cone}(S)cone(S) denotes the smallest cone containing S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn. This is well-defined.

Theorem (L2-1): given any collection of convex sets, their intersection is itself a convex set.

Proof: if the intersection is empty, then L2-1 is vacuously true. Otherwise, take any two points A,B in the intersection. The line AB joining these points must also lie wholly within each set in the collection, hence must lie wholly within their intersection.

Claim (L2-2): For any set X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn, there is a unique minimal convex set containing XXX.

Proof: take the intersection of all convex sets containing X.

Lemma (L2-3): for vector c∈Rn,S⊆Rnc\in \mathbb{R}^n, S\subseteq\mathbb{R}^nc∈Rn,S⊆Rn, the following problems have the same optimal value:

{min⁡(c⊺x:x∈S)min⁡(c⊺x:x∈conv(S))\begin{cases}\min(c^\intercal x:x\in S)\\\min(c^\intercal x: x\in\textrm{conv}(S))\end{cases} {min(c⊺x:x∈S)min(c⊺x:x∈conv(S))​

Proof: define (P.1)≔min⁡(c⊺x:x∈S),(P.2)≔min⁡(c⊺x:x∈conv(S))(P.1)\coloneqq \min(c^\intercal x:x\in S),(P.2)\coloneqq \min(c^\intercal x: x\in\textrm{conv}(S))(P.1):=min(c⊺x:x∈S),(P.2):=min(c⊺x:x∈conv(S)). Since S⊆conv(S),OPT(P.2)≤OPT(P.1)S\subseteq \textrm{conv}(S), \textrm{OPT}(P.2)\le\textrm{OPT}(P.1)S⊆conv(S),OPT(P.2)≤OPT(P.1). Next, let α=(P.1)\alpha=(\textrm{P.1})α=(P.1) and let half space H={x∈Rn:c⊺x≥α}H=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^n:c^\intercal x\ge \alpha\}H={x∈Rn:c⊺x≥α}. By definition S⊆HS\subseteq HS⊆H. HHH is a half space because the objective function is linear, if the objective function is non-linear then HHH is not a convex and the following steps wouldn't hold. Moreover, since HHH is convex, conv(S)⊆H\textrm{conv}(S)\subseteq Hconv(S)⊆H. It follows that OPT(P.2)≥α=OPT(P.1)\textrm{OPT}(P.2)\ge \alpha = \textrm{OPT}(P.1)OPT(P.2)≥α=OPT(P.1).

Carathéodory's theorem for Convex Sets: for S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn and x∈conv(S)x\in \textrm{conv}(S)x∈conv(S), there is a set S0⊆SS_0\subseteq SS0​⊆S of at most (n+1)(n+1)(n+1) points in SSS such that x∈conv(S0)x\in \textrm{conv}(S_0)x∈conv(S0​).

Lifting Lemma: given x∈Rn,S⊆Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^n, S\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn,S⊆Rn, we have x∈conv(S)x\in \textrm{conv}(S)x∈conv(S) if and only if [1x]∈cone({[1x]:x∈S})\begin{bmatrix}1\\x\end{bmatrix}\in\textrm{cone}\left( \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}1\\x\end{bmatrix}:x\in S \right\} \right)[1x​]∈cone({[1x​]:x∈S})

Proof: (⇒)(\Rightarrow)(⇒) ... (⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐) ...

Conical Combination Theorem (L2-4): for a1,…,ak∈Rna_1,\dots, a_k\in \mathbb{R}^na1​,…,ak​∈Rn, cone({a1,…,ak})={λ1a1+⋯+λkak:λ1,…,λk≥0}\textrm{cone}(\{a_1,\dots,a_k\})=\{\lambda_1 a_1 + \cdots + \lambda_k a_k:\lambda_1,\dots, \lambda_k\ge 0\}cone({a1​,…,ak​})={λ1​a1​+⋯+λk​ak​:λ1​,…,λk​≥0}

Proof: ...

Convex Combination Theorem (L2-5): for a1,…,ak∈Rna_1,\dots, a_k\in \mathbb{R}^na1​,…,ak​∈Rn, conv({a1,…,ak})={λ1a1+⋯+λkak:λ1,…,λk≥0,λ1+⋯+λk=1}\textrm{conv}(\{a_1,\dots,a_k\})=\{\lambda_1 a_1 + \cdots + \lambda_k a_k:\lambda_1,\dots, \lambda_k\ge 0, \lambda_1+\cdots + \lambda_k =1\}conv({a1​,…,ak​})={λ1​a1​+⋯+λk​ak​:λ1​,…,λk​≥0,λ1​+⋯+λk​=1}.

Proof: followed from L2-4 and Lifting Lemma.

Carathéodory's theorem for Cones: for S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn and x∈cone(S)x\in \textrm{cone}(S)x∈cone(S), there is a set S0⊆SS_0\subseteq SS0​⊆S of linearly independent vectors in SSS such that x∈cone(S0)x\in \textrm{cone}(S_0)x∈cone(S0​).

Proof: followed from L2-6 and L2-7

Lemma (L2-6): for S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn and x∈cone(S)x\in \textrm{cone}(S)x∈cone(S), there is a finite set S1⊆SS_1\subseteq SS1​⊆S of vectors in SSS such that x∈cone(S1)x\in \textrm{cone}(S_1)x∈cone(S1​).

Hint: Let ZZZ be the set of all points that are in the cone of some finite subset of SSS. Clearly Z⊆cone(S)Z\subseteq \textrm{cone}(S)Z⊆cone(S). To prove that cone(S)⊆Z\textrm{cone}(S)\subseteq Zcone(S)⊆Z, we need to prove that S⊆ZS\subseteq ZS⊆Z and ZZZ is a cone.

Lemma (L2-7): for a finite set S1⊆RnS_1\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS1​⊆Rn and x∈cone(S1)x\in\textrm{cone}(S_1)x∈cone(S1​), there is a set S0⊆S1S_0\subseteq S_1S0​⊆S1​ of linearly independent vectors such that x∈cone(S0)x\in \textrm{cone}(S_0)x∈cone(S0​).

Convex Function: Let S0⊆RnS_0\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS0​⊆Rn be a convex set. A function f:S0→Rf:S_0\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:S0​→R is a convex if for each x,y∈S0,α∈[0,1]x,y\in S_0, \alpha \in [0,1]x,y∈S0​,α∈[0,1], we have

f(αx+(1−α)y)≤αf(x)+(1−α)f(y)f(\alpha x + (1-\alpha)y)\le \alpha f(x)+(1-\alpha) f(y) f(αx+(1−α)y)≤αf(x)+(1−α)f(y)

Level Sets of Convex Functions: If f:S0→Rf:S_0\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:S0​→R is a convex function and α∈R\alpha\in \mathbb{R}α∈R, then the set S={x∈S0:f(x)≤α}S=\{x\in S_0:f(x)\le \alpha\}S={x∈S0​:f(x)≤α} is convex, and is called a level set. This is the convexity of level sets.

∀x,y∈S,λ∈[0,1]\forall x,y\in S, \lambda\in [0,1]∀x,y∈S,λ∈[0,1], we have f(λx+(1−λ)y)≤λf(x)+(1−λ)f(y)≤λα+(1−λ)α=αf(\lambda x+(1-\lambda)y)\le \lambda f(x)+(1-\lambda)f(y)\le \lambda\alpha+(1-\lambda)\alpha=\alphaf(λx+(1−λ)y)≤λf(x)+(1−λ)f(y)≤λα+(1−λ)α=α, so that λx+(1−λ)y∈S\lambda x+(1-\lambda)y\in Sλx+(1−λ)y∈S (convexity).

Note that level sets of non-convex functions can be convex, i.e. convexity of level sets does not characterize convex functions.

Epigraph of Convex Functions: the epigraph of a function f:S0→Rf:S_0\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:S0​→R, where S0⊆RnS_0\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS0​⊆Rn, is the subset of Rn+1\mathbb{R}^{n+1}Rn+1 defined by

epi(f)≔{[xz]∈Rn+1:z≥f(x),x∈S0}\textrm{epi}(f)\coloneqq\left\{ \begin{bmatrix}x\\z\end{bmatrix}\in\mathbb{R}^{n+1}:z\ge f(x),x\in S_0 \right\} epi(f):={[xz​]∈Rn+1:z≥f(x),x∈S0​}

Claim: f:S0→Rf:S_0\rightarrow \mathbb{R}f:S0​→R is convex if and only if epi(f)\textrm{epi}(f)epi(f) is convex.

Example 1, prove Arithmetic Mean - Geometric Mean Inequality, that is, for real numbers x1,…,xn>0x_1,\dots, x_n > 0x1​,…,xn​>0, 1n∑i=1nxi≥∏i=1nxin\displaystyle \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \ge \sqrt[\small n]{\prod_{i=1}^n x_i}n1​i=1∑n​xi​≥ni=1∏n​xi​​. Consider the problem

(P)≔minimize 1n∑i=1nxi subject to {x1…xnn≥1x1,x2,…,xn>0(P)\coloneqq\quad \textrm{minimize }\quad \displaystyle \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i \quad\textrm{ subject to }\quad \begin{cases} \sqrt[n]{x_1\dots x_n} \ge 1\\ x_1,x_2,\dots,x_n > 0 \end{cases} (P):=minimize n1​i=1∑n​xi​ subject to {nx1​…xn​​≥1x1​,x2​,…,xn​>0​

To prove the Arithmetic Mean - Geometric Mean Inequality, it suffices to prove that OPT(P)≥1\textrm{OPT}(P)\ge 1OPT(P)≥1. The following are equivalent:

{x1⋯xnn≥1x1⋯xn≥1−ln⁡(x1)−⋯−ln⁡(xn)≤0\begin{cases}\sqrt[n]{x_1\cdots x_n}\ge 1\\x_1\cdots x_n\ge 1\\ -\ln(x_1)-\cdots -\ln(x_n)\le 0\end{cases} ⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​nx1​⋯xn​​≥1x1​⋯xn​≥1−ln(x1​)−⋯−ln(xn​)≤0​

Note that f(x)=−ln⁡(x)f(x)=-\ln(x)f(x)=−ln(x) is a convex function on S0={x>0:x∈R}S_0=\{x>0:x\in \mathbb{R}\}S0​={x>0:x∈R}. We can therefore write (P)(P)(P) as

(P~)≔min⁡(c⊺x:f(x)≤0,x∈S0)(\widetilde{P}) \coloneqq \min(c^\intercal x : f(x)\le 0, x\in S_0) (P):=min(c⊺x:f(x)≤0,x∈S0​)

where c=[1/n …1/n]⊺,S0={x∈Rn:x>0}c=[1/n\ \dots 1/n]^\intercal, S_0=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^n:x>0\}c=[1/n …1/n]⊺,S0​={x∈Rn:x>0}, and for x∈S0x\in S_0x∈S0​, f(x)≔∑i=1n−ln⁡(xi)\displaystyle f(x)\coloneqq \sum_{i=1}^n -\ln(x_i)f(x):=i=1∑n​−ln(xi​). We see that the feasible region of (P~)(\widetilde{P})(P) is the level set of a convex function.

Example 2: (P)≔min⁡(sin⁡2(πx)+sin⁡2(πy)+sin⁡2(πz):x3+y3=z3,x,y,z≥1)(P)\coloneqq \min( \sin^2(\pi x)+\sin^2(\pi y)+\sin^2(\pi z):x^3+y^3=z^3, x,y,z\ge 1)(P):=min(sin2(πx)+sin2(πy)+sin2(πz):x3+y3=z3,x,y,z≥1). Note that OPT(P)≥0\textrm{OPT}(P)\ge 0OPT(P)≥0 and a feasible solution x,y,zx,y,zx,y,z has objective value zero if and only if x,y,zx,y,zx,y,z are positive integers satisfying x3+y3=z3x^3+y^3=z^3x3+y3=z3.

Example 3: a Diophantine Equation is an equation p(x1,…,xn)=0p(x_1,\dots, x_n)=0p(x1​,…,xn​)=0, where ppp is a polynomial with integer coefficients. Hilbert's 10th Problem: given a Diophantine Equation, decide whether it has an integer solution. We can formulate the problem as

(P)≔min⁡(∑i=1nsin⁡2πxi:p(x1,…,xn)=0)(P)\coloneqq \min\left( \sum_{i=1}^n\sin^2\pi x_i:p(x_1,\dots, x_n)=0 \right) (P):=min(i=1∑n​sin2πxi​:p(x1​,…,xn​)=0)

This problem is not decidable [Matiysevich, 1970]. Many famous theorems and conjectures can be reformulated in terms of solving Diophantine equations: Goldbach's conjecture, the Four Colour Theorem, Reimann Hypothesis, etc.

Systems of Linear Inequalities

Given A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm, does there exist x∈Rnx\in \mathbb{R}^nx∈Rn such that Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b?

Fourier-Motzkin Elimination: we start with a set of inequalities,

  1. Isolate one variable, for our purpose this variable is xxx, and arrange to LHS
  2. Let EEE denote the RHS expressions, we construct sets of RHS expressions:

    {L={E:x≥E}R={E:x≤E}\begin{cases}L=\{E:x\ge E\}\\R=\{E:x\le E\}\end{cases} {L={E:x≥E}R={E:x≤E}​

  3. Eliminate xxx via max⁡(L)≤min⁡(R)\max(L)\le\min(R)max(L)≤min(R), this expression is equivalent to a new set of inequalities:

    l≤r∀ l∈L,r∈Rl\le r\quad \forall\ l\in L, r\in R l≤r∀ l∈L,r∈R

Given a system of mmm inequalities, if we eliminate one variables, we have O(m2)O(m^2)O(m2) inequalities. After eliminating kkk variables we get O(m2k)O(m^{2^k})O(m2k) inequalities. This is highly inefficient.

Polyhedra and Projections

  • Polyhedron: a set of the form {x∈Rn:Ax≥b}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}{x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×n,b∈RmA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, b\in \mathbb{R}^mA∈Rm×n,b∈Rm.
  • Polytope is a bounded polyhedron.
  • Projection: let P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn, let l<nl<nl<n and P′={[x1⋮xl]:x∈P}P'=\left\{ \begin{bmatrix}x_1\\\vdots\\x_l\end{bmatrix}:x\in P \right\}P′=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​⎣⎢⎢⎡​x1​⋮xl​​⎦⎥⎥⎤​:x∈P⎭⎪⎪⎬⎪⎪⎫​. We call P′P'P′ the projection of PPP onto x1,…,xlx_1,\dots, x_lx1​,…,xl​.

Theorem (L4-1): if P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polyhedron and P′P'P′ is the projection of PPP onto x1,…,xlx_1,\dots,x_lx1​,…,xl​, then P′P'P′ is a polyhedron.

Proof: this follows from Fourier-Motzkin elimination. That is, if PPP is the feasible region of the original set of inequalities, then P′P'P′ the projection of PPP onto the new set of variables.

Corollary (L4-2): if X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn is a finite set, then conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is a polytope.

Proof: since XXX is finite, conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is bounded, so it remains to show that conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is a polyhedron. Let X={a1,…,am}X=\{a_1,\dots, a_m\}X={a1​,…,am​}, A=[a1,…,am]A=[a_1,\dots, a_m]A=[a1​,…,am​]. Recall that x∈conv(X)x\in\textrm{conv}(X)x∈conv(X) if and only if there exists λ∈Rm\lambda\in \mathbb{R}^mλ∈Rm such that x=Aλ, λ≥0x=A\lambda,\ \lambda\ge 0x=Aλ, λ≥0, and λ1+⋯+λm=1\lambda_1+\cdots +\lambda_m=1λ1​+⋯+λm​=1.

Let P+={[xλ]∈Rm+n:x∈Aλ,λ≥0,λ1+⋯+λm=1}P^+=\left\{ \begin{bmatrix}x\\\lambda\end{bmatrix}\in \mathbb{R}^{m+n}:x\in A\lambda, \lambda\ge 0, \lambda_1+\cdots+\lambda_m=1 \right\}P+={[xλ​]∈Rm+n:x∈Aλ,λ≥0,λ1​+⋯+λm​=1}. Note that P+P^+P+ is a polyhedron and conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is the projection of P+P^+P+ onto xxx, so conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is a polyhedron. How is P+P^+P+ polyhedron?

Given A∈Rn×m,λ∈Rm,x∈RnA\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times m},\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^m,x\in \mathbb{R}^nA∈Rn×m,λ∈Rm,x∈Rn, we can rearrange x=Aλx=A\lambdax=Aλ in polyhedron form:

[−I∣A][xλ]=0⃗(E.1)[-I|A]\begin{bmatrix}x\\\lambda\end{bmatrix}=\vec{0} \qquad(E.1) [−I∣A][xλ​]=0(E.1)

In 3D, for example, L1L^1L1 norm bound of λ\lambdaλ is an octahedron, but we only consider the first quadrant (λ≥0)(\lambda\ge 0)(λ≥0). We can rewrite the λ\lambdaλ constraint in matrix form

{(1⃗)⊺λ=1Iλ≥0⟺{(1⃗)⊺λ≥1(1⃗)⊺λ≤1Iλ≥0⃗⟺{(1⃗)⊺λ≥1−(1⃗)⊺λ≥−1Iλ≥0⃗⟺[(1⃗)⊺−(1⃗)⊺I]λ≥[1−10⃗](E.2)\begin{aligned} \begin{cases}(\vec{1})^\intercal \lambda = 1\\ I\lambda \ge 0\end{cases} &\Longleftrightarrow \begin{cases}(\vec{1})^\intercal\lambda \ge 1\\ (\vec{1})^\intercal \lambda\le 1\\ I\lambda \ge \vec{0}\end{cases}\\ &\Longleftrightarrow \begin{cases}(\vec{1})^\intercal\lambda \ge 1\\ -(\vec{1})^\intercal \lambda\ge -1\\ I\lambda \ge \vec{0}\end{cases}\\ &\Longleftrightarrow \begin{bmatrix}(\vec{1})^\intercal\\-(\vec{1})^\intercal\\I\end{bmatrix}\lambda\ge\begin{bmatrix}1\\-1\\\vec{0}\end{bmatrix} \qquad(E.2) \end{aligned} {(1)⊺λ=1Iλ≥0​​⟺⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​(1)⊺λ≥1(1)⊺λ≤1Iλ≥0​⟺⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​(1)⊺λ≥1−(1)⊺λ≥−1Iλ≥0​⟺⎣⎢⎡​(1)⊺−(1)⊺I​⎦⎥⎤​λ≥⎣⎢⎡​1−10​⎦⎥⎤​(E.2)​

At this point

  • (E.1)(E.1)(E.1) is a polyhedron P1P_1P1​
  • (E.2)(E.2)(E.2) is a polyhedron P2P_2P2​, we can "lift" it to the same dimension of P1P_1P1​ by adding 0⃗≥0⃗\vec{0}\ge \vec{0}0≥0, and get P2+P_2^+P2+​.
  • P+=P1∩P2+P^+=P_1\cap P_2^+P+=P1​∩P2+​

This follows from a lemma that the intersection of polyhedra is a polyhedron, which we left as an exercise ;)

Certifying Infeasibility

Recall the fundamental theorem of linear algebra: Let F\mathbb{F}F be a field, for A∈Fm×nA\in \mathbb{F}^{m\times n}A∈Fm×n and b∈Fmb\in \mathbb{F}^mb∈Fm exactly one of the following systems has a solution:

  1. (Ax=b,x∈Rn)(Ax=b, x\in \mathbb{R}^n)(Ax=b,x∈Rn)
  2. (y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y∈Rm)(y^\intercal A=0, y^\intercal b=1, y\in \mathbb{R}^m)(y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y∈Rm)

That is, if Ax=bAx=bAx=b is infeasible, then we can obtain the equation 0=10=10=1 by taking a linear combination of the rows. Additionally, how do you show that bbb is not spanned by columns of AAA? We can take a vector vvv that's orthogonal to the subspace spanned by AAA, and show that bbb is not orthogonal to vvv, i.e. (y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y∈Rm)(y^\intercal A=0, y^\intercal b=1, y\in \mathbb{R}^m)(y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y∈Rm)

Farkas' Lemma: Let A∈Rm×n,b∈RmA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, b\in \mathbb{R}^mA∈Rm×n,b∈Rm. Exactly one of the following systems has a solution:

  1. (Ax≥b,x∈Rn)(Ax\ge b, x\in \mathbb{R}^n)(Ax≥b,x∈Rn)
  2. (y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0,y∈Rm)(y^\intercal A=0, y^\intercal b=1, y\ge 0, y\in \mathbb{R}^m)(y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0,y∈Rm).

That is, if Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b has no solution then we can obtain the inequality 0≥10\ge 10≥1 as a non-negative combination of the constraints.

Claim (L5-1): for Farkas' Lemma, 1. and 2. cannot both hold.

Claim (L5-2): if Ax≥bAx \ge bAx≥b is infeasible, then 0≥10\ge 10≥1 is implied.

Proof: induction argument from L5-2-1 and L5-2-2

Claim (L5-2-1): if A′x≥b′A'x \ge b'A′x≥b′ is a set of inequalities implied by Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b, and A′′x≥b′′A'' x\ge b''A′′x≥b′′ is a set of inequalities implied by A′x≥b′A'x\ge b'A′x≥b′, then A′′x≥b′′A'' x\ge b''A′′x≥b′′ is implied by Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b.

Claim (L5-2-2): the system obtained from Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b by Fourier-Motzkin Elimination is implied.

Farkas' Lemma alternate form: Let A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm. Then exactly one of the following systems has a solution:

  1. (Ax=b,x≥0)(Ax=b, x\ge 0)(Ax=b,x≥0)
  2. (y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1)(y^\intercal A \ge 0, y^\intercal b= -1)(y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1)

Proof: Easy part: if xxx satisfies (1.) and yyy satisfies (2.) then we have contradiction. So (1.) and (2.) cannot both have a solution.

Hard Part: if (1.) has no solution, then (2.) has a solution. We can rewrite (1.) as (Ax≥b,Ax≤b,x≥0)(Ax\ge b, Ax\le b, x\ge 0)(Ax≥b,Ax≤b,x≥0), or equivalently, [A−AI]x≥[b−b0]≕(1.′)\begin{bmatrix}A\\-A\\I\end{bmatrix}x\ge \begin{bmatrix}b\\-b\\0\end{bmatrix}\eqqcolon(1.')⎣⎢⎡​A−AI​⎦⎥⎤​x≥⎣⎢⎡​b−b0​⎦⎥⎤​=:(1.′). If (1.′)(1.')(1.′) has no solution, then by the Farkas Lemma, there exists non-negative vectors y1,y2∈Rm,z∈Rny_1, y_2\in \mathbb{R}^m, z\in \mathbb{R}^ny1​,y2​∈Rm,z∈Rn such that [y1y2z]⊺[A−AI]=0\begin{bmatrix}y_1\\y_2\\z\end{bmatrix}^\intercal\begin{bmatrix}A\\-A\\I\end{bmatrix}=0⎣⎢⎡​y1​y2​z​⎦⎥⎤​⊺⎣⎢⎡​A−AI​⎦⎥⎤​=0, and [y1y2z]⊺[b−b0]=1\begin{bmatrix}y_1\\y_2\\z\end{bmatrix}^\intercal\begin{bmatrix}b\\-b\\0\end{bmatrix}=1⎣⎢⎡​y1​y2​z​⎦⎥⎤​⊺⎣⎢⎡​b−b0​⎦⎥⎤​=1, that is {y1⊺A−y2⊺A+z=0y1⊺b−y2⊺b=1\begin{cases}y_1^\intercal A-y_2^\intercal A+z&=0\\y_1^\intercal b-y_2^\intercal b&=1\end{cases}{y1⊺​A−y2⊺​A+zy1⊺​b−y2⊺​b​=0=1​, we can rewrite this as {(y2−y1)⊺A≥0(y2−y1)⊺b=−1\begin{cases}(y_2-y_1)^\intercal A\ge 0\\(y_2-y_1)^\intercal b= -1\end{cases}{(y2​−y1​)⊺A≥0(y2​−y1​)⊺b=−1​. Letting y=y2−y1y=y_2-y_1y=y2​−y1​, which gives a solution to (y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1)(y^\intercal A\ge 0, y^\intercal b= -1)(y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1).

This alternate form gives a nice geometric interpretation. Suppose that A=[a1,…,an]A=[a_1,\dots, a_n]A=[a1​,…,an​], we have:

  1. ∃x∈Rn\exists x\in \mathbb{R}^n∃x∈Rn such that Ax=b,x≥0⟺b∈cone({a1,a2,…,an})Ax=b, x\ge 0 \Longleftrightarrow b\in\textrm{cone}(\{a_1,a_2, \dots,a_n\})Ax=b,x≥0⟺b∈cone({a1​,a2​,…,an​})
  2. Let closed half space H={x∈Rn:y⊺x≥0}H=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:y^\intercal x\ge 0\}H={x∈Rn:y⊺x≥0}. Note that a1,…,an∈Ha_1,\dots, a_n\in Ha1​,…,an​∈H, but not bbb. Therefore, (y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1)⟺(y^\intercal A\ge 0, y^\intercal b = -1)\Longleftrightarrow(y⊺A≥0,y⊺b=−1)⟺ there is a closed half-space containing a1,…,ana_1,\dots, a_na1​,…,an​ but not bbb.

Geometry of Polyhedra

Definitions:

  • Extreme Point: let S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn be a convex set and x∈Sx\in Sx∈S, we call x∈Sx\in Sx∈S an extreme point of SSS if there are no two distinct points x1,x2x_1, x_2x1​,x2​ in SSS such that x∈{λx1+(1−λ)x2:0<λ<1}x\in \{\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda)x_2:0<\lambda<1\}x∈{λx1​+(1−λ)x2​:0<λ<1}.
  • Equality Subsystem: let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm, and let x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P. The equality subsystem for x~\tilde{x}x~ is the subsystem of Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b, denoted A=≥b=A^=\ge b^=A=≥b=, such that A=x~=b=A^= \tilde{x} = b^=A=x~=b=.
  • Hyperplane: a hyperplane of Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn is a set of the form {x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:a^\intercal x=a_0\}{x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0​}, where a∈Rn\{0}a\in \mathbb{R}^n\backslash \{0\}a∈Rn\{0}.
  • Supporting Hyperplane: a supporting hyperplane for a set S⊆RnS\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS⊆Rn is a hyperplane H={x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0}H=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:a^\intercal x = a_0\}H={x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0​} such that SSS is contained in either half plane {x∈Rn:a⊺x≥a0}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:a^\intercal x\ge a_0\}{x∈Rn:a⊺x≥a0​} or {x∈Rn:a⊺x≤a0}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:a^\intercal x \le a_0\}{x∈Rn:a⊺x≤a0​}, and S∩H≠ϕS\cap H\neq \phiS∩H​=ϕ.

To extend on Corollary (L4-2):

Theorem (L6-1): a set P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polytope if and only if P=conv(X)P=\textrm{conv}(X)P=conv(X) for some finite set X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn.

Proof: we will show

  1. Polyhedra have only finitely many extreme points
  2. Every polytope is the convex hull of its extreme points.

Theorem (L6-2): a set P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polytope if and only if P=conv(X)P=\textrm{conv}(X)P=conv(X) for some finite set X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn.

Extreme Points Characterization Theorem: let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm, let x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P and let A=x≥b=A^= x\ge b^=A=x≥b= be the equality subsystem. rank(A=)=n\textrm{rank}(A^=)=nrank(A=)=n if and only if x~\tilde{x}x~ is an extreme point.

Proof: (⇒)(\Rightarrow)(⇒) Contrapositive, suppose that x~\tilde{x}x~ is not an extreme point, so there exist distinct x1,x2∈Px_1, x_2\in Px1​,x2​∈P and λ∈(0,1)\lambda\in (0,1)λ∈(0,1) such that x~=λx1+(1−λ)x2\tilde{x}=\lambda x_1 + (1-\lambda) x_2x~=λx1​+(1−λ)x2​. Note that b==A=x~=λA=x1+(1−λ)A=x2≥λb=+(1−λ)b==b=b^==A^= \tilde{x}=\lambda A^=x_1+(1-\lambda) A^= x_2\ge \lambda b^=+(1-\lambda) b^==b^=b==A=x~=λA=x1​+(1−λ)A=x2​≥λb=+(1−λ)b==b=. Since we can't have A=x1<b=A^=x_1<b^=A=x1​<b= or A=x2<b=A^=x_2 < b^=A=x2​<b=, we get A=x1=b=A^=x_1=b^=A=x1​=b= and A=x2=b=A^= x_2 = b^=A=x2​=b=, and therefore A=(x2−x1)=0A^=(x_2-x_1)=0A=(x2​−x1​)=0. By rank theorem, since x2−x1≠0x_2-x_1\neq 0x2​−x1​​=0, we have rank(A=)<n\textrm{rank}(A^=)<nrank(A=)<n.

(⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐): Contrapositive, we show that if rank(A=)<n\textrm{rank}(A^=)<nrank(A=)<n, then x~\tilde{x}x~ is not an extreme point. If rank(A=)<n\textrm{rank}(A^=)<nrank(A=)<n, then ∃\exists∃ non-zero d∈Rnd\in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn such that A=d=0A^= d=0A=d=0. Consequently, A=(x~+λd)=b=∀λ∈RA^=(\tilde{x}+\lambda d)=b^=\forall \lambda\in \mathbb{R}A=(x~+λd)=b=∀λ∈R. Then, ∃ϵ>0\exists \epsilon > 0∃ϵ>0 such that x~+ϵd,x~−ϵd∈P\tilde{x}+\epsilon d, \tilde{x}-\epsilon d\in Px~+ϵd,x~−ϵd∈P, and hence x~\tilde{x}x~ is not an extreme point.□\square□

Corollary (L6-3): polyhedra have only finitely many extreme points.

Proof: let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm. Now consider an extreme point x~\tilde{x}x~ and its associated equality subsystem A=x≥b=A^=x\ge b^=A=x≥b=. By extreme points characterization theorem, rank(A=)=n\textrm{rank}(A^=)=nrank(A=)=n. Therefore x~\tilde{x}x~ is the unique solution to A=x=b=A^= x= b^=A=x=b=. There are only 2m2^m2m subsystems of Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b, so there are at most 2m2^m2m extreme points.□\square□

Theorem (L6-4): every polytope is the convex hull of its extreme points.

Proof: Let xxx be the set of extreme points of a polytope P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}. Clearly conv(X)⊆P\textrm{conv}(X)\subseteq Pconv(X)⊆P. Assume by way of contradiction that there exists x~∈P\conv(X)\tilde{x}\in P\backslash \textrm{conv}(X)x~∈P\conv(X) and choose such x~\tilde{x}x~ whose equality subsystem A=x≥b=A^= x\ge b^=A=x≥b= contains as many constraints as possible. Since x~∉conv(X)\tilde{x}\notin \textrm{conv}(X)x~∈/​conv(X), x~\tilde{x}x~ is not an extreme point and hence rank(A=)<n\textrm{rank}(A^=)<nrank(A=)<n. So there is a nonzero vector ddd such that A=d=0A^=d=0A=d=0. Let

{λ+=max⁡(λ∈R:x~+λd∈P)λ−=min⁡(λ∈R:x~+λd∈P)\begin{cases} \lambda^+=\max(\lambda\in \mathbb{R}:\tilde{x}+\lambda d\in P)\\ \lambda^-=\min(\lambda\in \mathbb{R}:\tilde{x}+\lambda d\in P)\end{cases}{λ+=max(λ∈R:x~+λd∈P)λ−=min(λ∈R:x~+λd∈P)​

Now let x1=x~+λ+d,x2=x~+λ−dx_1=\tilde{x}+\lambda^+ d,x_2=\tilde{x}+\lambda^- dx1​=x~+λ+d,x2​=x~+λ−d. We have A=x1=b=,A=x2=b=A^=x_1 = b^=, A^=x_2=b^=A=x1​=b=,A=x2​=b=. Therefore, by our choice of λ−,λ+\lambda^-, \lambda^+λ−,λ+, we have λ−<0<λ+\lambda^- <0<\lambda^+λ−<0<λ+, and both x1,x2x_1, x_2x1​,x2​ have more equality constraints than x~\tilde{x}x~ does. By our choice of x~\tilde{x}x~, we have x1,x2∈conv(X)x_1,x_2\in \textrm{conv}(X)x1​,x2​∈conv(X). Then, since x~\tilde{x}x~ is on the line segment between x1,x2x_1, x_2x1​,x2​, we have x~∈conv(X)\tilde{x}\in \textrm{conv}(X)x~∈conv(X).□\square□

Theorem (L6-5): if x~\tilde{x}x~ is an extreme point of a polyhedron P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn, then there is a supporting hyperplane HHH such that P∩H={x~}P\cap H=\{\tilde{x}\}P∩H={x~}.

Proof: Suppose that P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} and let [a1 ⋯ ak]⊺x≥[b1 ⋯ bk]⊺[a_1\ \cdots\ a_k]^\intercal x\ge [b_1\ \cdots\ b_k]^\intercal[a1​ ⋯ ak​]⊺x≥[b1​ ⋯ bk​]⊺ be the equality constraints for x~\tilde{x}x~. Let a=a1+⋯+ak,a0=b1+⋯+bka=a_1+\cdots + a_k, a_0=b_1+\cdots + b_ka=a1​+⋯+ak​,a0​=b1​+⋯+bk​ and H={x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0}H=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:a^\intercal x = a_0\}H={x∈Rn:a⊺x=a0​}. Consider any point x~∈P∩H\tilde{x}\in P\cap Hx~∈P∩H. We have

a0=a⊺x~=a1⊺x~+⋯+ak⊺x~⏟definition of H≥b1+⋯+bk=a0⏟definition of P\underbrace{a_0=a^\intercal \tilde{x}=a_1^\intercal \tilde{x}+\cdots + a_k^\intercal \tilde{x}}_\textrm{definition of H} \underbrace{\ge b_1+\cdots + b_k=a_0}_\textrm{definition of P}definition of Ha0​=a⊺x~=a1⊺​x~+⋯+ak⊺​x~​​definition of P≥b1​+⋯+bk​=a0​​​

Therefore, a1⊺x~=b1,…,ak⊺x~=bka_1^\intercal \tilde{x}=b_1,\dots, a_k^\intercal \tilde{x}=b_ka1⊺​x~=b1​,…,ak⊺​x~=bk​. However, the equality system for x~\tilde{x}x~ has a unique solution, namely x~\tilde{x}x~, and hence H∩P={x~}H\cap P=\{\tilde{x}\}H∩P={x~}. □\square□

Theorem (L7-1): if a system of mmm linear equations in nnn variables is infeasible, then there is an infeasible subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 equations. Equivalently, if H1,…,HmH_1,\dots, H_mH1​,…,Hm​ are hyperplanes in Rm\mathbb{R}^mRm with empty intersection, then there is a subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of these hyperplanes with empty intersection. (This is a special case of Helly's Theorem)

Proof: From Ax=bAx=bAx=b where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n, we select k≤nk\le nk≤n linearly independent rows from AAA to be A1A_1A1​, and let the rest of the rows go into A2A_2A2​, and we have {A1x=b1A2x=b2\begin{cases}A_1 x=b_1\\A_2 x=b_2\end{cases}{A1​x=b1​A2​x=b2​​. If A1x=b1A_1 x=b_1A1​x=b1​ is inconsistent, then we are done. Otherwise, since rows of A1A_1A1​ are spans AAA, we can find a linear combination of rows from A1A_1A1​ for each row in A2A_2A2​, substituting, and system A2x=b2A_2 x = b_2A2​x=b2​ will become inconsistent. Since A1A_1A1​ has at most nnn rows, we need one more row from A2x=b2A_2 x=b_2A2​x=b2​, i.e. (0x⃗=b~)(0\vec{x}=\tilde{b})(0x=b~) to make the system inconsistent.□\square□

Theorem (L7-2): if a system of mmm linear inequalities in nnn variables is infeasible, then there is an infeasible subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of the inequalities. Equivalently, if H1,…,HmH_1, \dots, H_mH1​,…,Hm​ are closed half-spaces in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn with empty intersection, then there is a subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of these half-spaces with empty intersection.

Proof: Consider an infeasible system of inequalities [a1 ⋯ am]⊺x≥[α1 … αm][a_1\ \cdots\ a_m]^\intercal x \ge [\alpha_1\ \dots\ \alpha_m][a1​ ⋯ am​]⊺x≥[α1​ … αm​]. By the Farkas Lemma, there exist non-negative numbers y1,…,ym∈Ry_1,\dots, y_m\in \mathbb{R}y1​,…,ym​∈R such that a1y1+⋯+amym=0⃗a_1 y_1 + \cdots+a_m y_m=\vec{0}a1​y1​+⋯+am​ym​=0 and α1y1+⋯+αmym=1\alpha_1 y_1 + \cdots + \alpha_m y_m=1α1​y1​+⋯+αm​ym​=1. That is,

[0⃗1]∈cone({[a1α1],…,[amαm]})\begin{bmatrix}\vec{0}\\1\end{bmatrix}\in\textrm{cone}\left( \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}a_1\\\alpha_1\end{bmatrix},\dots,\begin{bmatrix}a_m\\\alpha_m\end{bmatrix} \right\} \right) [01​]∈cone({[a1​α1​​],…,[am​αm​​]})

By Caratheodory's Theorem for cones, up to possible reordering, we may assume that

[0⃗1]∈cone({[a1α1],…,[akαk]})\begin{bmatrix}\vec{0}\\1\end{bmatrix}\in\textrm{cone}\left( \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}a_1\\\alpha_1\end{bmatrix},\dots,\begin{bmatrix}a_k\\\alpha_k\end{bmatrix} \right\} \right) [01​]∈cone({[a1​α1​​],…,[ak​αk​​]})

where [a1α1],…,[akαk]∈Rn+1\begin{bmatrix}a_1\\\alpha_1\end{bmatrix},\dots,\begin{bmatrix}a_k\\\alpha_k\end{bmatrix}\in \mathbb{R}^{n+1}[a1​α1​​],…,[ak​αk​​]∈Rn+1 are linearly independent. We also have k≤n+1k\le n+1k≤n+1. Now by Farkas Lemma (second time), the system a1⊺x≥α1,…,ak⊺≥αka_1^\intercal x\ge \alpha_1, \dots, a_k^\intercal \ge \alpha_ka1⊺​x≥α1​,…,ak⊺​≥αk​ is infeasible. □\square□

Helly's Theorem for Polyhedra: if H1,…,HmH_1, \dots, H_mH1​,…,Hm​ are polyhedra in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn with empty intersection, then there is a subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of these polyhedra with empty intersection.

Proof: each of the polyhedra is itself an intersection of finitely many closed, so this result follows from the previous one. □\square□

Helly's Theorem: if S1,…,Sm⊆RnS_1,\dots, S_m\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nS1​,…,Sm​⊆Rn are convex sets with S1∩⋯∩Sm=ϕS_1\cap \dots\cap S_m=\phiS1​∩⋯∩Sm​=ϕ, then there is a subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of these sets that has empty intersection.

Proof: suppose that the result fails for S1,…,SmS_1, \dots, S_mS1​,…,Sm​. Then there is a set X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn of at most (mn+1){m\choose n+1}(n+1m​) such that each subcollection of n+1n+1n+1 of the sets S1,…,SmS_1,\dots, S_mS1​,…,Sm​ contain a common element in XXX. Let P1=conv(S1∩X),…,Pm=conv(Sm∩X)P_1=\textrm{conv}(S_1\cap X), \dots, P_m=\textrm{conv}(S_m\cap X)P1​=conv(S1​∩X),…,Pm​=conv(Sm​∩X). Note that P1,…,PmP_1,\dots, P_mP1​,…,Pm​ are polytopes (since each is the convex hull of a finite set), and P1∩P2∩⋯∩Pm⊆S1∩S2∩⋯∩Sm=ϕP_1\cap P_2\cap \dots\cap P_m\subseteq S_1\cap S_2\cap \dots \cap S_m=\phiP1​∩P2​∩⋯∩Pm​⊆S1​∩S2​∩⋯∩Sm​=ϕ. However any subcollection of at most n+1n+1n+1 of P1,…,PmP_1,\dots, P_mP1​,…,Pm​ contain a common element in XXX. This contradicts Helly's Theorem for Polyhedra, and such XXX does not exist. □\square□

Question: would this still h old if we took infinitely many sets?

No, S1=[1,∞),S2=[2,∞),…S_1=[1,\infty), S_2=[2,\infty), \dotsS1​=[1,∞),S2​=[2,∞),…

Exercise: prove that, if S1,S2,…S_1, S_2,\dotsS1​,S2​,… is an infinite sequence of compact sets in Rn\mathbb{R}^nRn that have empty intersection, then there is a finite subcollection with empty intersection. (This is a special case of Heine-Borel Theorem.)

Unbounded Polyhedra

Definition:

  • Set Addition: for set X,Y⊆RnX,Y \subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX,Y⊆Rn, we define X+Y≔x∈X,y∈Y}X+Y \coloneqq x\in X, y\in Y\}X+Y:=x∈X,y∈Y}.
  • Line: line(x~,d~)≔{x~+λd~:λ∈R}\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})\coloneqq\{\tilde{x}+\lambda\tilde{d}:\lambda\in \mathbb{R}\}line(x~,d~):={x~+λd~:λ∈R}
  • Ray: ray(x,d)≔{x+λd:λ∈R,λ≥0}\textrm{ray}(x,d)\coloneqq \{x+\lambda d:\lambda\in \mathbb{R},\lambda\ge 0\}ray(x,d):={x+λd:λ∈R,λ≥0}
  • Pointed Polyhedra: a polyhedron is pointed if it is non-empty and does not contain a line.
  • Polyhedral Cone: a polyhedron that is a cone.

Lemma (L8-1): let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:A x\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} be a polyhedron, let x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P and let d~∈Rn\tilde{d}\in \mathbb{R}^nd~∈Rn. Then ray(x~,d~)⊆P⟺Ad~≥0\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})\subseteq P \Longleftrightarrow A\tilde{d}\ge 0ray(x~,d~)⊆P⟺Ad~≥0

Lemma (L8-2): let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} be a polyhedron, let x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P and let d~∈Rn\tilde{d}\in \mathbb{R}^nd~∈Rn. Then PPP contains line(x~,d~)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})line(x~,d~) if and only if Ad~=0A\tilde{d}=0Ad~=0.

Corollary (L8-3): a polyhedron is pointed if and only if it has an extreme point.

Remark: if P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polyhedron containing a line L=line(x~,d~)L=\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})L=line(x~,d~) and H⊆RnH\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nH⊆Rn is a hyperplane not containing LLL, then P=(P∩H)+{λd~:λ∈R}=(P∩H)+cone({d~,−d~})P= (P\cap H)+\{\lambda\tilde{d}:\lambda\in \mathbb{R}\}=(P\cap H)+\textrm{cone}(\{\tilde{d},-\tilde{d}\})P=(P∩H)+{λd~:λ∈R}=(P∩H)+cone({d~,−d~}).

Theorem (L8-4): if P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a non-empty polyhedra, then there is a pointed polyhedra P0⊆PP_0\subseteq PP0​⊆P and a finite set D⊆RnD\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nD⊆Rn such that P=P0+cone(D)P=P_0+\textrm{cone}(D)P=P0​+cone(D).

Proof: suppose that P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n, and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm. Define S={d∈Rn:Ad=0}S=\{d\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ad=0\}S={d∈Rn:Ad=0}, and its orthogonal space S⊥≔{x∈Rn:x⊺d=0∀d∈S}S^\perp \coloneqq \{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:x^\intercal d = 0 \forall d\in S\}S⊥:={x∈Rn:x⊺d=0∀d∈S}, and let P0=P∩S⊥P_0=P\cap S^\perpP0​=P∩S⊥. We need to show that

  1. P=P0+SP=P_0+SP=P0​+S, from linear algebra, each point z∈Rnz\in \mathbb{R}^nz∈Rn can be written uniquely as x+dx+dx+d where x∈S⊥x\in S^\perpx∈S⊥ and d∈Sd\in Sd∈S. We know z∈Pz\in Pz∈P if and only if x∈Px\in Px∈P. Therefore P=P0+SP=P_0+SP=P0​+S.
  2. P0P_0P0​ does not contain a line: recall that PPP contains line(x~,d~)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})line(x~,d~) if and only if x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P and d~∈S\{0}\tilde{d}\in S\backslash \{0\}d~∈S\{0}, so P0=P∩S⊥P_0=P\cap S^\perpP0​=P∩S⊥ cannot contain any such line.

And we are done. □\square□

Theorem (L9-1): let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} be a pointed polyhedron where A∈Rm×nA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}A∈Rm×n and b∈Rmb\in \mathbb{R}^mb∈Rm, let XXX be the set of extreme points of PPP and let K={x∈Rn:Ax≥0}K=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n: Ax\ge 0\}K={x∈Rn:Ax≥0}, then P=conv(X)+KP=\textrm{conv}(X)+KP=conv(X)+K.

Proof: (conv(X)+K)⊆P)(\textrm{conv}(X)+K) \subseteq P)(conv(X)+K)⊆P): implied by Lemma L8-1.

(P⊆conv(X)+K)(P\subseteq \textrm{conv}(X)+K)(P⊆conv(X)+K): Assume for a contradiction that P\(conv(X)+K)≠ϕP\backslash (\textrm{conv}(X)+K)\neq \phiP\(conv(X)+K)​=ϕ, and we pick x~∈P\(conv(X)+K)\tilde{x}\in P\backslash (\textrm{conv}(X)+K)x~∈P\(conv(X)+K) to be the point that satisfies the most number of constraints with equality. Let A=≥b=A^= \ge b^=A=≥b= be the equality subsystem for x~\tilde{x}x~. Since x~∉X\tilde{x}\notin Xx~∈/​X, we have rank(A=)<n\textrm{rank}(A^=)<nrank(A=)<n, and therefore there exists non-zero vector d~∈Rn\tilde{d}\in \mathbb{R}^nd~∈Rn such that A=d~=0A^= \tilde{d}=0A=d~=0. Note that:

  1. Each point on line(x~,d~)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})line(x~,d~) satisfies A=x=b=A^= x = b^=A=x=b=.
  2. All points on line(x~,d~)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x}, \tilde{d})line(x~,d~) that are sufficiently close to x~\tilde{x}x~ are contained in PPP.
  3. PPP cannot contain both ray(x~,d~)\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})ray(x~,d~) and ray(x~,−d~)\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},-\tilde{d})ray(x~,−d~) (since PPP is pointed)

Suppose WLOG that ray(x~,−d~)⊈P\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},-\tilde{d})\nsubseteq Pray(x~,−d~)⊈P (we could replace ddd with −d-d−d otherwise). We have

  • Case 1 (ray(x~,d~)⊈P)(\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})\nsubseteq P)(ray(x~,d~)⊈P): we choose λ−=min⁡(λ∈R:x~+λd~∈P)\lambda^-=\min(\lambda\in \mathbb{R}:\tilde{x}+\lambda \tilde{d}\in P)λ−=min(λ∈R:x~+λd~∈P) and λ+=max⁡(λ∈R:x~+λd~∈P)\lambda^+=\max(\lambda\in \mathbb{R}:\tilde{x}+\lambda \tilde{d}\in P)λ+=max(λ∈R:x~+λd~∈P). These exist since PPP is closed and since PPP does not contain either ray(x~,d~)\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})ray(x~,d~) or ray(x~,−d~)\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},-\tilde{d})ray(x~,−d~). Let x1=x~+λ−d~x_1=\tilde{x}+\lambda^- \tilde{d}x1​=x~+λ−d~ and x2=x~+λ+d~x_2=\tilde{x}+\lambda^+ \tilde{d}x2​=x~+λ+d~. Note that the equality subsystems for both x1x_1x1​ and x2x_2x2​ contain more inequalities than A=x≥b=A^=x\ge b^=A=x≥b=, so by our choice of x~\tilde{x}x~, x1,x2∈conv(X)+K⟹x~∈conv(X)+Kx_1, x_2 \in \textrm{conv}(X)+K \Longrightarrow \tilde{x}\in\textrm{conv}(X)+Kx1​,x2​∈conv(X)+K⟹x~∈conv(X)+K. We arrive at the contradiction.
  • Case 2 (ray(x~,d~)⊆P)(\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})\subseteq P)(ray(x~,d~)⊆P): by Lemma L8-1 d~∈K\tilde{d}\in Kd~∈K. Choose λ~=max⁡(λ∈R:x~−λd~∈P)\tilde{\lambda}=\max(\lambda\in \mathbb{R}:\tilde{x}-\lambda \tilde{d}\in P)λ~=max(λ∈R:x~−λd~∈P). This is well-defined since PPP is closed and ray(x~,−d~)⊈P\textrm{ray}(\tilde{x},-\tilde{d})\nsubseteq Pray(x~,−d~)⊈P. Define x^=x~−λ~d~\hat{x}=\tilde{x}-\tilde{\lambda}\tilde{d}x^=x~−λ~d~. Now x^\hat{x}x^ satisfies more of the constraints Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b with equality than x^\hat{x}x^ does. So by our choice of x~,x^∈conv(x)+K⟹x~∈conv(X)+K\tilde{x}, \hat{x}\in \textrm{conv}(x)+K\Longrightarrow \tilde{x}\in \textrm{conv}(X)+Kx~,x^∈conv(x)+K⟹x~∈conv(X)+K.

Note that this theorem also implies Corollary L8-3. □\square□

Lemma (L9-2): let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Rm×n,b∈RmA\in \mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, b\in \mathbb{R}^mA∈Rm×n,b∈Rm. If PPP is a cone, then P={x∈Rn:Ax≥0}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge 0\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥0}.

Theorem (L9-3): if K⊆RnK\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nK⊆Rn is a polyhedral cone, then there is a finite set D⊆KD\subseteq KD⊆K such that K=cone(D)K=\textrm{cone}(D)K=cone(D).

Proof: let B={x∈Rn:−1⃗≤x≤1⃗}B=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:-\vec{1}\le x\le \vec{1}\}B={x∈Rn:−1≤x≤1}. Note that B∩KB\cap KB∩K is a polytope and K=cone(B∩K)K=\textrm{cone}(B\cap K)K=cone(B∩K). Let DDD be the set of extreme points of B∩KB\cap KB∩K. Thus B∩K=conv(D)B\cap K=\textrm{conv}(D)B∩K=conv(D) and hence K=cone(B∩K)=cone(conv(D))=cone(D)K=\textrm{cone}(B\cap K)=\textrm{cone}(\textrm{conv}(D))=\textrm{cone}(D)K=cone(B∩K)=cone(conv(D))=cone(D).□\square□

Theorem (L9-4): a set P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polyhedron if and only if P=conv(X)+cone(D)P=\textrm{conv}(X)+\textrm{cone}(D)P=conv(X)+cone(D) for some X,D⊆RnX,D\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX,D⊆Rn.

Proof: (⇐)(\Leftarrow)(⇐) if X,D⊆RnX,D\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX,D⊆Rn are finite sets, then conv(X)+cone(D)\textrm{conv}(X)+\textrm{cone}(D)conv(X)+cone(D) is a polyhedron. We show:

  1. If X⊆RnX\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX⊆Rn is a finite set, then conv(X)\textrm{conv}(X)conv(X) is a polytope. (Theorem L6-1)
  2. If D⊆RnD\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nD⊆Rn is a finite set, then cone(D)\textrm{cone}(D)cone(D) is a polyhedron. (Exercise)
  3. If P1,P2⊆RnP_1, P_2\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP1​,P2​⊆Rn are polyhedra, then P1+P2P_1+P_2P1​+P2​ is a polyhedron. (Exercise)

(⇒)(\Rightarrow)(⇒) if P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is a polyhedron, then there exist finite sets X,D⊆RnX,D \subseteq \mathbb{R}^nX,D⊆Rn such that P=conv(X)+cone(D)P=\textrm{conv}(X)+\textrm{cone}(D)P=conv(X)+cone(D). Suppose PPP is non-empty, then by theorem L8-4 there is a pointed polyhedra P0⊆PP_0\subseteq PP0​⊆P and a finite set D1⊆RnD_1\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nD1​⊆Rn such that P=P0+cone(D1)P=P_0+\textrm{cone}(D_1)P=P0​+cone(D1​). Since P0P_0P0​ is a pointed polyehedra, by theorem L9-1, we can write P0=conv(X)+KP_0=\textrm{conv}(X)+KP0​=conv(X)+K where XXX is the set of extreme points and KKK is a polyhedral cone. Now, by theorem L9-3, we know K=cone(D2)K=\textrm{cone}(D_2)K=cone(D2​) where D2⊆RnD_2\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nD2​⊆Rn is finite. Therefore P=(conv(X)+cone(D2))+cone(D1)=conv(X)+cone(D1∪D2)P=(\textrm{conv}(X)+\textrm{cone}(D_2))+\textrm{cone}(D_1)=\textrm{conv}(X)+\textrm{cone}(D_1\cup D_2)P=(conv(X)+cone(D2​))+cone(D1​)=conv(X)+cone(D1​∪D2​). □\square□

Linear Optimization

Fundamental Theorem of Linear Programming

Unboundedness Theorem: given problem P≔min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)P\coloneqq \min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)P:=min(c⊺x:Ax≥b), we say (P)(P)(P) is unbounded if and only if (P)(P)(P) is feasible and there exists d∈Rnd\in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn such that Ad≥0Ad\ge 0Ad≥0 and c⊺d<0c^\intercal d<0c⊺d<0. (vector ddd is a ray, recall L8-1)

Remark: unbounded theorem does not extend to non-linear optimization problems, for example, min⁡(y:y≥−x,x≥0)\min(y:y\ge -\sqrt{x}, x\ge 0)min(y:y≥−x​,x≥0) is unbounded, but there is no feasible ray with unbounded objective value. How do you certify that (P)(P)(P) is unbounded? You could provide a ray, and show that the objective value is decreasing along the ray, i.e. minimum value does not exist.

Certifying boundedness using implied inequality (show that c⊺xc^\intercal xc⊺x is at least some constant), example: Given a primal problem:

(P)≔{min⁡(x1+x2)subject to2x1+x2≥4y1(a)2x1+3x2≥6y2(b)x1+4x3≥4y3(c)(P)\coloneqq \begin{cases}\min & (x_1+x_2)\\ \textrm{subject to}& 2x_1+x_2\ge 4 &&y_1\quad (a)\\ & 2x_1+3x_2\ge 6 && y_2\quad (b)\\ & x_1+4x_3 \ge 4 &&y_3\quad (c) \end{cases} (P):=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​minsubject to​(x1​+x2​)2x1​+x2​≥42x1​+3x2​≥6x1​+4x3​≥4​​y1​(a)y2​(b)y3​(c)​

Each implied inequality has the form:

(2y1+2y2+y3)x1+(y1+3y2+4y3)x2≥4y1+6y2+4y3,y1,y2,y3≥0(2y_1 + 2y_2+y_3)x_1+(y_1+3y_2+4y_3)x_2 \ge 4y_1+6 y_2 + 4 y_3, \qquad y_1, y_2, y_3 \ge 0 (2y1​+2y2​+y3​)x1​+(y1​+3y2​+4y3​)x2​≥4y1​+6y2​+4y3​,y1​,y2​,y3​≥0

We have the implied inequality:

{2y1+2y2+y3=1y1+3y2+4y3=1⟹x1+x2≥4y1+6y2+4y3\begin{cases}2 y_1 + 2y_2 + y_3 = 1\\ y_1 + 3y_2 + 4y_3 = 1\end{cases} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad x_1 + x_2 \ge 4 y_1 + 6 y_2 + 4 y_3 {2y1​+2y2​+y3​=1y1​+3y2​+4y3​=1​⟹x1​+x2​≥4y1​+6y2​+4y3​

We arrive at the dual problem:

(D)≔{max⁡(4y1+6y2+4y3)subject to2y1+2y2+y3=1y1+3y2+4y3=1y1,y2,y3≥0(D)\coloneqq \begin{cases} \max & (4 y_1 + 6 y_2 + 4 y_3)\\ \textrm{subject to} & 2 y_1 + 2 y_2 + y_3 = 1\\ & y_1 + 3 y_2 + 4 y_3 = 1\\ & y_1, y_2, y_3 \ge 0 \end{cases} (D):=⎩⎪⎪⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎪⎪⎧​maxsubject to​(4y1​+6y2​+4y3​)2y1​+2y2​+y3​=1y1​+3y2​+4y3​=1y1​,y2​,y3​≥0​

More generally, consider

  • Primary Problem (P)(P)(P): min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)\min(c^\intercal x: Ax\ge b)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)
  • Dual Problem (D)(D)(D): max⁡(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)\max(b^\intercal y: A^\intercal y = c, y\ge 0)max(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)

Weak Duality Theorem: if xxx is a feasible solution to (P)(P)(P) and yyy is a feasible solution to (D)(D)(D), then c⊺x≥b⊺yc^\intercal x \ge b^\intercal yc⊺x≥b⊺y, i.e. OPT(D)≤OPT(P)\textrm{OPT}(D) \le \textrm{OPT}(P)OPT(D)≤OPT(P)

Corollaries (L10-1):

  1. If (D)(D)(D) is feasible, then (P)(P)(P) is bounded
  2. If (P)(P)(P) is feasible, then (D)(D)(D) is bounded
  3. If xxx is feasible for (P)(P)(P), yyy is feasible for (D)(D)(D), and c⊺x=b⊺yc^\intercal x = b^\intercal yc⊺x=b⊺y, then xxx is optimal for (P)(P)(P) and yyy is optimal for (D)(D)(D).

Strong Duality Theorem: if (P)(P)(P) has an optimal solution, then (D)(D)(D) has an optimal solution, and OPT(P)=OPT(D)\textrm{OPT}(P)=\textrm{OPT}(D)OPT(P)=OPT(D)

Optimality Condition: a feasible solution x~\tilde{x}x~ for (P)(P)(P) is optimal if and only if there is a feasible solution y~\tilde{y}y~​ for (D)(D)(D) with b⊺y~=c⊺x~b^\intercal \tilde{y}=c^\intercal \tilde{x}b⊺y~​=c⊺x~.

Uber Theorem, only one of the following can be true:

  1. (P)(P)(P) and (D)(D)(D) both have optimal solutions and OPT(P)=OPT(D)\textrm{OPT}(P)=\textrm{OPT}(D)OPT(P)=OPT(D)
  2. There exists y∈Rmy \in \mathbb{R}^my∈Rm such that (y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0)(y^\intercal A=0, y^\intercal b = 1, y\ge 0)(y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0) and, hence, (P)(P)(P) is infeasible. (Farkas' Lemma)
  3. (P)(P)(P) is feasible and there exists d∈Rnd\in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn such that (c⊺d<0,Ad≥0)(c^\intercal d < 0, Ad\ge 0)(c⊺d<0,Ad≥0) and hence, (P)(P)(P) is unbounded.

Uber Theorem ... simplified: A linear program can only be one of the following,

  • infeasible
  • unbounded
  • has an optimal solution

Remark: Uber theorem implies the fundamental theorem, the unboundedness theorem, and the strong duality theorem.

Proof: we will assume that neither (I) nor (II) hold, and will show that (III) holds. By the Farkas' Lemma, since (II) does not hold, (P)(P)(P) is feasible. (I) could be rewritten as

{(A)Ax≥b,A⊺y=c,y≥0,c⊺x≤b⊺y(statement 1.)(B)A⊺y=zc,Ax≥zb,b⊺y−c⊺x=1,y≥0,z≥0\begin{cases} \textrm{(A)}\quad Ax\ge b, A^\intercal y=c,y\ge 0, c^\intercal x \le b^\intercal y\qquad(\textrm{statement 1.})\\ \textrm{(B)}\quad A^\intercal y=zc, Ax\ge zb, b^\intercal y - c^\intercal x = 1, y\ge 0, z\ge 0 \end{cases} {(A)Ax≥b,A⊺y=c,y≥0,c⊺x≤b⊺y(statement 1.)(B)A⊺y=zc,Ax≥zb,b⊺y−c⊺x=1,y≥0,z≥0​

We claim that exactly one of (A),(B)(A), (B)(A),(B) has a solution (assignment exercise). Since (I) does not hold, there is a solution xˉ∈Rn,yˉ∈Rm,zˉ∈R\bar{x}\in \mathbb{R}^n, \bar{y}\in \mathbb{R}^m, \bar{z}\in \mathbb{R}xˉ∈Rn,yˉ​∈Rm,zˉ∈R to (B)(B)(B). We then claim that zˉ=0\bar{z}=0zˉ=0 (assignment exercise).

Now xˉ,yˉ\bar{x},\bar{y}xˉ,yˉ​ satisfy: A⊺yˉ=0,Axˉ≥0,b⊺yˉ−c⊺xˉ>0,y≥0A^\intercal \bar{y}=0, A\bar{x}\ge 0, b^\intercal \bar{y}-c^\intercal \bar{x}>0, y\ge 0A⊺yˉ​=0,Axˉ≥0,b⊺yˉ​−c⊺xˉ>0,y≥0. We have either:

  • Case 1: A⊺yˉ=0,b⊺yˉ>0,yˉ≥0A^\intercal \bar{y}=0, b^\intercal \bar{y} > 0, \bar{y}\ge 0A⊺yˉ​=0,b⊺yˉ​>0,yˉ​≥0, which contradicts the fact (P)(P)(P) is feasible.
  • Case 2: Axˉ≥0,c⊺xˉ<0A\bar{x}\ge 0, c^\intercal \bar{x}<0Axˉ≥0,c⊺xˉ<0, as required.

We therefore proved (III). □\square□

Duality-Problem Case Study

A general example:

(P)≔{max⁡c⊺xsubject toAx≤bx≥0(P)\coloneqq \begin{cases} \max & c^\intercal x\\ \textrm{subject to}& Ax\le b\\ &x\ge 0 \end{cases} (P):=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​maxsubject to​c⊺xAx≤bx≥0​

Implied inequality of Ax≤bAx\le bAx≤b have the form (y⊺A)x≤y⊺b(y^\intercal A)x\le y^\intercal b(y⊺A)x≤y⊺b, given y≥0y\ge 0y≥0, and we want

c⊺x≤(y⊺A)x≤y⊺bc^\intercal x \le (y^\intercal A)x\le y^\intercal b c⊺x≤(y⊺A)x≤y⊺b

We arrive at the dual:

(D)≔{min⁡b⊺ysubject toA⊺y≥cy≥0(D)\coloneqq \begin{cases} \min & b^\intercal y\\ \textrm{subject to} & A^\intercal y \ge c\\ & y\ge 0 \end{cases} (D):=⎩⎪⎪⎨⎪⎪⎧​minsubject to​b⊺yA⊺y≥cy≥0​

Another specific example:

Optimality Criteria for Linear Optimization

(P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(D)max⁡(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)\begin{aligned} (P)\qquad &\min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)\\ (D)\qquad &\max(b^\intercal y : A^\intercal y = c, y\ge 0) \end{aligned}(P)(D)​min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)max(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)​

Proof: let x~∈S1∩⋯∩Sm\tilde{x}\in S_1\cap\cdots\cap S_mx~∈S1​∩⋯∩Sm​. For each i∈{1,…,m}i\in \{1,\dots, m\}i∈{1,…,m}, we have ci⊺x~≥ci⊺xˉc_i^\intercal \tilde{x}\ge c_i^\intercal \bar{x}ci⊺​x~≥ci⊺​xˉ, so

Interesting physical interpretation:

Simplex Method

Optimization Problem

Given A∈Qm×n,b∈Qn,c∈QnA\in \mathbb{Q}^{m\times n},b\in \mathbb{Q}^n, c\in \mathbb{Q}^nA∈Qm×n,b∈Qn,c∈Qn, consider the linear program

(P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(D)max⁡(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)\begin{aligned} (P)\qquad &\min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)\\ (D)\qquad &\max(b^\intercal y : A^\intercal y = c, y\ge 0) \end{aligned}(P)(D)​min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)max(b⊺y:A⊺y=c,y≥0)​

Feasibility Problem (recall): find either

  1. x~∈Qn\tilde{x}\in \mathbb{Q}^nx~∈Qn to (P)(P)(P), or
  2. y∈Qmy\in \mathbb{Q}^my∈Qm such that (y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0)(y^\intercal A=0,y^\intercal b=1, y\ge 0)(y⊺A=0,y⊺b=1,y≥0)

Optimization Problem: given a feasible solution x~∈Qn\tilde{x}\in \mathbb{Q}^nx~∈Qn, find either

  1. A feasible solution x∗x^*x∗ to (P)(P)(P) and a feasible solution y∗y^*y∗ to (D)(D)(D) with c⊺x∗=b⊺y∗c^\intercal x^*=b^\intercal y^*c⊺x∗=b⊺y∗, or
  2. A vector d~∈Qn\tilde{d}\in \mathbb{Q}^nd~∈Qn such that (c⊺d<0,Ad~≥0)(c^\intercal d<0, A\tilde{d}\ge 0)(c⊺d<0,Ad~≥0).

Claim (L13-1): the feasibility problem and the optimization problems are equivalent.

Proof: we could rewrite the two statements of the optimization problem,

  • Solve (Ax≥b,A⊺y=c,y≥0,c⊺x=b⊺y)(Ax\ge b, A^\intercal y=c, y\ge 0, c^\intercal x=b^\intercal y)(Ax≥b,A⊺y=c,y≥0,c⊺x=b⊺y)
  • Solve (c⊺x=−1,Ax≥0)(c^\intercal x = -1, Ax\ge 0)(c⊺x=−1,Ax≥0)

By now you should be really familiar with these, they appeared in Assignment 2, and are used to prove the Uber theorem. Regardless, these two conditions are equivalent to the two conditions in Farkas' Lemma. □\square□

Given a problem

(P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(AP)min⁡(s1+⋯+sm:Ax+s≥b,s≥0)\begin{aligned} (P)\qquad &\min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)\\ (AP)\qquad &\min(s_1+\cdots + s_m:Ax+s\ge b, s\ge 0) \end{aligned}(P)(AP)​min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)min(s1​+⋯+sm​:Ax+s≥b,s≥0)​

Claim (L13-2): (P)(P)(P) is feasible if and only if OPT(AP)=0\textrm{OPT}(AP)=0OPT(AP)=0.

Proof: Assignment 4 Q1. □\square□

Claim (L13-3): If (P)(P)(P) is infeasible, then by Strong Duality Theorem, we can prove Farkas' Lemma, i.e. y∈Rmy\in \mathbb{R}^my∈Rm such that (A⊺y=0,b⊺y=1,y≥0)(A^\intercal y=0, b^\intercal y=1, y\ge 0)(A⊺y=0,b⊺y=1,y≥0)

Finding Extreme Points

The simplex method depends on the existence of extreme points. However, not all polyhedrons have extreme points.

Given a polyhedron P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{ x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} and problem

(P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(P)\quad \min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b) (P)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)

Recall the following are equivalent:

  • PPP has no extreme point
  • PPP contains a line
  • rank(A)<n\textrm{rank}(A)<nrank(A)<n

Suppose that PPP does not have an extreme point. We need to transform PPP to artificially create extreme points.

Solution 1: replace (P)(P)(P) by (P~)min⁡(c⊺(x1−x2):A(x1−x2)≥b,x1,x2≥0)(\tilde{P})\quad \min(c^\intercal (x_1-x_2) : A(x_1-x_2)\ge b, x_1, x_2\ge 0)(P~)min(c⊺(x1​−x2​):A(x1​−x2​)≥b,x1​,x2​≥0). Splitting the variable creates a new polyhedron P~={[x1x2]:[A−AIOOI][x1x2]≥[b0⃗0⃗]}∈R2n\tilde{P} = \left\{ \begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix} : \begin{bmatrix}A &-A\\I & O\\ O & I\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}x_1\\x_2\end{bmatrix}\ge\begin{bmatrix}b\\\vec{0}\\\vec{0}\end{bmatrix} \right\} \in \mathbb{R}^{2n}P~=⎩⎪⎨⎪⎧​[x1​x2​​]:⎣⎢⎡​AIO​−AOI​⎦⎥⎤​[x1​x2​​]≥⎣⎢⎡​b00​⎦⎥⎤​⎭⎪⎬⎪⎫​∈R2n. And then for n≥2n\ge 2n≥2, we have rank([A−AIOOI])=2n⟺P~\textrm{rank}\left( \begin{bmatrix}A &-A\\I & O\\ O & I\end{bmatrix} \right)=2n\Longleftrightarrow \tilde{P}rank⎝⎜⎛​⎣⎢⎡​AIO​−AOI​⎦⎥⎤​⎠⎟⎞​=2n⟺P~ has extreme points.

To visualize it in 2D, the constraint x1,x2≥0x_1, x_2\ge 0x1​,x2​≥0 means the new polyhedron is contained in the first quadrant, which does not contain a line.

This solution is easy, but it doubles the number of variables unnecessarily.

Solution 2: we "squeeze" the polyhedron by projections until there is an extreme point. Suppose that rank(A)<n\textrm{rank}(A)<nrank(A)<n, and let d~∈Rn\tilde{d}\in \mathbb{R}^nd~∈Rn be a non-zero vector such that Ad~=0A\tilde{d}=0Ad~=0. That is, line(x~,d~)∈P\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\tilde{d})\in Pline(x~,d~)∈P.

  • Claim 1: If c⊺d~≠0c^\intercal \tilde{d}\neq 0c⊺d~​=0, then (P)(P)(P) is unbounded. (By possibly replacing d~\tilde{d}d~ with −d~-\tilde{d}−d~, we may assume that c⊺d~<0c^\intercal \tilde{d}<0c⊺d~<0. Then by the unboundedness theorem, (P)(P)(P) is unbounded.) Therefore, we may assume that c⊺d=0c^\intercal d = 0c⊺d=0.
  • Claim 2: If d~i≠0\tilde{d}_i\neq 0d~i​​=0, then for each x∈Px\in Px∈P there exists x′=x−λd~∈Px'=x-\lambda \tilde{d}\in Px′=x−λd~∈P such that c⊺x′=c⊺xc^\intercal x' = c^\intercal xc⊺x′=c⊺x and xi′=0x_i'=0xi′​=0. (Let λ=xi/d~\lambda=x_i/\tilde{d}λ=xi​/d~ and let x′=x−λd~x'=x-\lambda \tilde{d}x′=x−λd~, then xi′=xi−xi−(x/d~i)d~i=0x_i' = x_i- x_i - (x/\tilde{d}_i)\tilde{d}_i=0xi′​=xi​−xi​−(x/d~i​)d~i​=0.) Geometrically, this means all points on line(x,d~)⊆P\textrm{line}(x, \tilde{d})\subseteq Pline(x,d~)⊆P have the same objective value that could be represented by a single point x′x'x′ whose xi′=0x_i' = 0xi′​=0.
  • Now we apply the "squeeze".

Squeeze (L13-4): Let (P′)(P')(P′) be the problem obtained from (P)(P)(P) by setting xi=0x_i = 0xi​=0, i.e. projecting the polyhedron to all variables except xix_ixi​. Now, (P′)(P')(P′) has fewer variables than (P)(P)(P) and by the claim, OPT(P)=OPT(P′)\textrm{OPT}(P)=\textrm{OPT}(P')OPT(P)=OPT(P′).

Henceforth, we shall assume that rank(A)=n\textrm{rank}(A)=nrank(A)=n and hence that PPP has an extreme point.

Extreme Point Algorithm:

  1. Construct the equality subsystem A=x≥b=A^= x\ge b^=A=x≥b= for x~\tilde{x}x~. If rank(A=)=n\textrm{rank}(A^=)=nrank(A=)=n, STOP (x~\tilde{x}x~ is an extreme point)
  2. Find a nonzero vector d∈Rnd\in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn such that A=d=0A^= d = 0A=d=0. If Ad≥0Ad\ge 0Ad≥0, replace ddd with −d-d−d.
  3. Let λ−=max⁡(λ∈R:x+λd∈P)\lambda^-=\max(\lambda \in \mathbb{R}:x+\lambda d\in P)λ−=max(λ∈R:x+λd∈P). Replace x~\tilde{x}x~ with x~+λ−d\tilde{x}+\lambda^- dx~+λ−d. Repeat from step 1.

Exercise (L13-5): revise the algorithm so that it finds either:

  1. An extreme point xˉ\bar{x}xˉ with c⊺xˉ≤c⊺x~c^\intercal \bar{x}\le c^\intercal \tilde{x}c⊺xˉ≤c⊺x~.
  2. A vector d∈Rnd\in \mathbb{R}^nd∈Rn such that (c⊺d<0,Ad≥0)(c^\intercal d<0, Ad\ge 0)(c⊺d<0,Ad≥0).

Simplex Algorithm

Consider (P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(P)\quad\min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)(P)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)

  • Problem: given an extreme point x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P with equality subsystem A=x≥b=A^= x\ge b^=A=x≥b=, solve (P)(P)(P).
  • Idea: move from extrem point to extreme point around the boundary improving the objective value.
  • Optimality Condition: x~\tilde{x}x~ is optimal for (P)(P)(P) if and only if there exists a solution to

    ((A=)⊺y=c,y≥0)((A^=)^\intercal y=c, y\ge 0) ((A=)⊺y=c,y≥0)

Remark: if A=A^=A= is square and nonsingular (invertible), then there is a unique solution y~\tilde{y}y~​ to (A=)⊺y=c(A^=)^\intercal y=c(A=)⊺y=c. Then x~\tilde{x}x~ is optimal if and only if y~≥0\tilde{y}\ge 0y~​≥0. Then, we can extend y~\tilde{y}y~​ to an optimal solution for (D)(D)(D) by setting y~i=0\tilde{y}_i=0y~​i​=0 for all non-equality constraints. (Here you really want to be careful about indicies.)

Degneracy: since rank(A=)=n\textrm{rank}(A^=)=nrank(A=)=n for extreme points, x~\tilde{x}x~ is the unique solution to A=x~=b=A^=\tilde{x}=b^=A=x~=b=. If A=A^=A= has more than nnn rows, then A=x=b=A^= x=b^=A=x=b= is over-determined. In this case, we call x~\tilde{x}x~ degenerate.

Revised Problem: Given a nondegenerate extreme point x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P. Let A=x≥b=A^= x\ge b^=A=x≥b= be the equality subsystem for x~\tilde{x}x~. Solve (A=)⊺y=c(A^=)^\intercal y=c(A=)⊺y=c for y~\tilde{y}y~​. Let BBB be the indices of the equality constraints, that is, A=∈RB×nA^=\in \mathbb{R}^{B\times n}A=∈RB×n and y~∈RB\tilde{y}\in \mathbb{R}^By~​∈RB.

Suppose y~j<0\tilde{y}_j<0y~​j​<0. Define vector ej∈RBe_j\in \mathbb{R}^Bej​∈RB such that index j∈Bj\in Bj∈B of eje_jej​ is 1 and the rest of the entries are 0. Let dˉ∈Rn\bar{d}\in \mathbb{R}^ndˉ∈Rn denote the unique solution to A=d=ejA^= d = e_jA=d=ej​.

Claim (L14-1): c⊺dˉ<0c^\intercal \bar{d}<0c⊺dˉ<0

Proof: c⊺d=(yˉ⊺A=)dˉ=yˉ⊺ej=yˉj<0c^\intercal d=(\bar{y}^\intercal A^=)\bar{d}=\bar{y}^\intercal e_j=\bar{y}_j<0c⊺d=(yˉ​⊺A=)dˉ=yˉ​⊺ej​=yˉ​j​<0

Claim (L14-1): For sufficiently small ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0, x~+εdˉ\tilde{x}+\varepsilon \bar{d}x~+εdˉ is feasible for (P)(P)(P).

Proof: it suffices to prove that, for each i∈{1,…,m},ai⊺(x~+εdˉ)≥bii\in \{1,\dots, m\}, a_i^\intercal (\tilde{x}+\varepsilon \bar{d})\ge b_ii∈{1,…,m},ai⊺​(x~+εdˉ)≥bi​ for sufficiently small ε>0\varepsilon >0ε>0.

  • If i∉Bi\notin Bi∈/​B, then ai⊺x~>bia_i^\intercal \tilde{x} > b_iai⊺​x~>bi​ and hence ai⊺(x~+εdˉ)≥bia_i^\intercal (\tilde{x}+\varepsilon \bar{d})\ge b_iai⊺​(x~+εdˉ)≥bi​ for small ε>0\varepsilon > 0ε>0.
  • If i∈Bi\in Bi∈B, then ai⊺a_i^\intercalai⊺​ is a row of A=A^=A=, so

    ai⊺(x~+εdˉ)={bi+ε,i=jbi,otherwisea_i^\intercal (\tilde{x}+\varepsilon \bar{d})=\begin{cases}b_i+\varepsilon, &i=j\\b_i,&\textrm{otherwise}\end{cases} ai⊺​(x~+εdˉ)={bi​+ε,bi​,​i=jotherwise​

We now attempt to find a more optimal extreme point:

  • Case 1: Ad~≥0A\tilde{d} \ge 0Ad~≥0. Then by the unboundedness theorem, (P)(P)(P) is unbounded.
  • Case 2: Ad~≱0A\tilde{d} \ngeq 0Ad~≱0. Choose the maximum λ∈R\lambda\in \mathbb{R}λ∈R such that x~+λdˉ∈P\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d}\in Px~+λdˉ∈P.

Claim (L14-3): x~+λdˉ\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d}x~+λdˉ is an extreme point and c⊺(x~+λdˉ)<c⊺x~c^\intercal(\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d})<c^\intercal \tilde{x}c⊺(x~+λdˉ)<c⊺x~.

Proof: by Claim L14-1 and L14-2, c⊺(x~+λdˉ)<c⊺x~c^\intercal (\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d})<c^\intercal \tilde{x}c⊺(x~+λdˉ)<c⊺x~. The equality subsystem for x~+λdˉ\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d}x~+λdˉ contains all of the constraints indexed by B\{j}B\backslash \{j\}B\{j}, which determine line(x~,dˉ)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\bar{d})line(x~,dˉ). Moreover, the definition of λ\lambdaλ provides an additional equality constraint which is not satisfied by all points on line(x~,dˉ)\textrm{line}(\tilde{x},\bar{d})line(x~,dˉ). So x~+λdˉ\tilde{x}+\lambda \bar{d}x~+λdˉ is uniquely determined by its equality subsystem and hence x~+λdˉ\tilde{x}+\lambda\bar{d}x~+λdˉ is extreme. □\square□

Simplex Algorithm: given an extreme point solution x~\tilde{x}x~ to (P)(P)(P).\

  1. Check nondegeneracy: let B={i∈{1,…,m}:ai⊺x~=bi}B=\{i\in\{1,\dots,m\}:a_i^\intercal \tilde{x}=b_i\}B={i∈{1,…,m}:ai⊺​x~=bi​}, let N={1,…,m}\BN=\{1,\dots,m\}\backslash BN={1,…,m}\B, and let A=x≥b=A^=x\ge b^=A=x≥b= be the equality subsystem for x~\tilde{x}x~. If ∣B∣≠n|B|\neq n∣B∣​=n, STOP (x~\tilde{x}x~ is degenerate).
  2. Test for optimality: solve (A=)⊺y=c(A^=)^\intercal y=c(A=)⊺y=c for y~∈RB\tilde{y}\in \mathbb{R}^By~​∈RB. If y~≥0\tilde{y}\ge 0y~​≥0, STOP (x~\tilde{x}x~ is optimal.)
  3. Choose leaving constraint: choose j∈Bj\in Bj∈B such that y~j<0\tilde{y}_j<0y~​j​<0.
  4. Check unboundedness: solve A=d=ejA^= d= e_jA=d=ej​ for d~\tilde{d}d~ and let z=Ad~z=A\tilde{d}z=Ad~. If z≥0z\ge 0z≥0, STOP ((P)(P)(P) is unbounded).
  5. Choose entering constraint: choose i∈Ni\in \mathbb{N}i∈N with zi<0z_i<0zi​<0, and minimize −(ai⊺x~−bi)/zi-(a_i^\intercal \tilde{x}-b_i)/z_i−(ai⊺​x~−bi​)/zi​.
  6. Update: let λ=−(ai⊺x~−bi)/zi\lambda = -(a_i^\intercal \tilde{x}-b_i)/z_iλ=−(ai⊺​x~−bi​)/zi​, replace x~\tilde{x}x~ with x~+λd~\tilde{x}+\lambda\tilde{d}x~+λd~, and repeat from step 1.

Remark: if there are no degenerate extreme points, then the algorithm will terminate (since there are at most (mn){m\choose n}(nm​) extreme points) and will solve (P)(P)(P) correctly.

Perturbation Method

Idea: we "perturb" the degenerate extreme point to make it non-degenerate.

Given a problem (P)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)(P)\quad \min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b)(P)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b). We "perturb" the system by introduce an indeterminate ε\varepsilonε, that we think of as a small positive real number. And we arrive at a modified problem (P′)(P')(P′):

(P′)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b′, bi′=bi−εi)(P')\quad \min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b',\ b'_i =b_i-\varepsilon^i) (P′)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b′, bi′​=bi​−εi)

For polynomials p(ε)p(\varepsilon)p(ε) and q(ε)q(\varepsilon)q(ε), we write p(ε)<q(ε)p(\varepsilon)<q(\varepsilon)p(ε)<q(ε) if p(ε′)<q(ε′)p(\varepsilon')<q(\varepsilon')p(ε′)<q(ε′) for all sufficiently small ε′>0\varepsilon'>0ε′>0. For example, 1+ε+1000ε2<1+2ε1+\varepsilon + 1000\varepsilon^2 <1 +2\varepsilon1+ε+1000ε2<1+2ε.

Claim (L15-1): (P′)(P')(P′) has no degenerate extreme points.

Proof: consider an extreme point x~\tilde{x}x~ of (P′)(P')(P′) Let X={i∈{1,…,m}:ai⊺x~=bi′}X=\{i\in\{1,\dots, m\}: a_i^\intercal \tilde{x}=b_i'\}X={i∈{1,…,m}:ai⊺​x~=bi′​}. If x~\tilde{x}x~ is degenerate, then the vectors {ai:i∈X}\{a_i:i\in X\}{ai​:i∈X} are linearly dependent. So there is a nonzero vector λ∈RX\lambda\in \mathbb{R}^Xλ∈RX such that ∑i∈Xλiai=0\displaystyle \sum_{i\in X} \lambda_i a_i=0i∈X∑​λi​ai​=0. Thus,

0=∑i∈Xλiai⊺x~=∑i∈Xλibi′=∑i∈Xλi(bi−εi)0=\sum_{i\in X} \lambda_i a_i^\intercal \tilde{x}=\sum_{i\in X} \lambda_i b_i' =\sum_{i\in X}\lambda_i(b_i-\varepsilon^i) 0=i∈X∑​λi​ai⊺​x~=i∈X∑​λi​bi′​=i∈X∑​λi​(bi​−εi)

However, since λ≠0\lambda\neq 0λ​=0, ∑i∈Xλi(bi−εi)\displaystyle \sum_{i\in X}\lambda_i(b_i-\varepsilon^i)i∈X∑​λi​(bi​−εi) is a non-zero polynomial in ε\varepsilonε, hence the contradiction. □\square□

Remarks:

  1. Since (P′)(P')(P′) is nondegenerate, the simplex method will terminate.
  2. There is some computational overhead in applying this method, but we can switch between (P)(P)(P) and (P′)(P')(P′) easily, so we need only use (P′)(P')(P′) when we are at a degenerate solution for (P)(P)(P).
  3. If the equality subsystem has m′m'm′ constraints, we need only perturb m′−nm'-nm′−n of them, keeping x~\tilde{x}x~ extreme.

Example: note that the objective value "improved" from 333 to 3−2ε3-2\varepsilon3−2ε. When the constant term improves, we set the ε\varepsilonε's to zero and continue using the simplex method until the next time we encounter a degenerate extreme point, at which point we apply a new perturbation.

Integer Linear Optimization

An integer linear optimization problem is a problem of the form (given A∈Rm×n,b∈Rm,c∈RnA\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times n}, b\in \mathbb{R}^m, c\in \mathbb{R}^nA∈Rm×n,b∈Rm,c∈Rn.)

(IP)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b,x∈Zn)\textrm{(IP)}\quad \min(c^\intercal x: Ax\ge b, x\in \mathbb{Z}^n) (IP)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b,x∈Zn)

The linear relaxation of (IP)\textrm{(IP)}(IP) is

(LP)min⁡(c⊺x:Ax≥b)\textrm{(LP)}\quad \min(c^\intercal x:Ax\ge b) (LP)min(c⊺x:Ax≥b)

Note that OPT(LP)≤OPT(IP)\textrm{OPT(LP)}\le \textrm{OPT(IP)}OPT(LP)≤OPT(IP) since each feasible solution to (IP)\textrm{(IP)}(IP) is feasible for (LP)\textrm{(LP)}(LP).

Let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} and let Z=P∩ZnZ=P\cap \mathbb{Z}^nZ=P∩Zn. Thus PPP is the feasible region for (LP)\textrm{(LP)}(LP) and ZZZ is the feasible region for (IP)\textrm{(IP)}(IP). Note that conv(Z)⊆P\textrm{conv}(Z)\subseteq Pconv(Z)⊆P; equality is rare, even when AAA and bbb are integer-valued.

Integral Polyhedron: a polyhedron P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is integral if P=conv(P∩Zn)P=\textrm{conv}(P\cap \mathbb{Z}^n)P=conv(P∩Zn). Note that, if PPP is integral, then

min⁡(c⊺x:x∈P∩Zn)=min⁡(c⊺x:x∈P) ∀c∈Rn\min(c^\intercal x: x\in P\cap \mathbb{Z}^n)=\min(c^\intercal x: x\in P)\ \forall c^\in \mathbb{R}^n min(c⊺x:x∈P∩Zn)=min(c⊺x:x∈P) ∀c∈Rn

That is, OPT(IP)=OPT(LP)\textrm{OPT(IP)}=\textrm{OPT(LP)}OPT(IP)=OPT(LP).

Lemma (L16-1): a polytope P⊆RnP\subseteq \mathbb{R}^nP⊆Rn is integral if and only if its extreme points are integer valued.

Proof: a polytope is the convex hull of its extreme points.

Theorem (L16-2): Let P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} where A∈Zm×nA\in \mathbb{Z}^{m\times n}A∈Zm×n and b∈Zmb\in \mathbb{Z}^mb∈Zm. If PPP is pointed, then PPP is integral if and only if all of ts extreme points are integral.

Proof: hint: P=conv(X)+{x∈Rn:Ax≥0}P=\textrm{conv}(X)+\{x\in\mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge 0\}P=conv(X)+{x∈Rn:Ax≥0} where XXX is the set of extreme points of PPP.)

Totally Unimodular Matrices: a matrix is totally unimodular (TU) if each of its square submatrices has determinant 0,±10,\pm 10,±1. (In particular, the entries must be 0,±10,\pm 10,±1).

Construction of TU matrices: let A∈{0,±1}m×nA\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times n}A∈{0,±1}m×n be TU. Then

  1. A⊺A^\intercalA⊺ is TU
  2. [I ∣ A][I\ |\ A][I ∣ A] is TU.
  3. If A′A'A′ is obtained from AAA by scaling a row or column by −1-1−1, then A′A'A′ is TU.
  4. [A ∣−A][A\ | -A][A ∣−A] is TU.

Lemma (L16-3): let A∈{0,±1}m×nA\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times n}A∈{0,±1}m×n be TU and b∈Zmb\in \mathbb{Z}^mb∈Zm. Then the extreme points of P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} are integer valued.

Proof: let x~∈Rn\tilde{x}\in \mathbb{R}^nx~∈Rn be an extreme point of PPP. Then there is a subsystem A′x≥b′A'x\ge b'A′x≥b′ of Ax≥bAx\ge bAx≥b such that A′x~=b′A' \tilde{x} = b'A′x~=b′ and A′A'A′ is n×nn\times nn×n and non-singular. Since AAA is TU, det⁡(A′)=±1\det(A')=\pm 1det(A′)=±1.

By Cramer's rule, each entry of (A′)−1(A')^{-1}(A′)−1 is integer valued. Hence each entry of x~=(A′)−1b′\tilde{x}=(A')^{-1} b'x~=(A′)−1b′ is integer valued.□\square□

Lemma (L16-4): If A∈{0,±1}A\in \{0,\pm 1\}A∈{0,±1} is TU, b∈Zm,l,u∈Znb\in \mathbb{Z}^m, l,u\in \mathbb{Z}^nb∈Zm,l,u∈Zn, then P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b, l\le x\le u\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u} is integral.

Proof: we can write PPP as {x∈Rn:A′x≥b′}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n: A'x\ge b'\}{x∈Rn:A′x≥b′} where A′=[AI−I]A'=\begin{bmatrix}A\\I\\-I\end{bmatrix}A′=⎣⎢⎡​AI−I​⎦⎥⎤​ and b′=[bl−u]b'=\begin{bmatrix}b\\l\\-u\end{bmatrix}b′=⎣⎢⎡​bl−u​⎦⎥⎤​. By the constructions, A′A'A′ is TU. By the previous lemma, each extreme point of PPP is integer valued. Moreover, PPP is a polytope (since l≤x≤ul\le x\le ul≤x≤u for each x∈Px\in Px∈P). So PPP is integral.

Theorem (L16-5): if A∈{0,±1}m×nA\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times n}A∈{0,±1}m×n is TU and b∈Zmb\in \mathbb{Z}^mb∈Zm, then P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b}P=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b\}P={x∈Rn:Ax≥b} is integral.

Proof: let x~∈P\tilde{x}\in Px~∈P and for each i∈{1,…,n}i\in \{1,\dots, n\}i∈{1,…,n}, define li≔⌊x~i⌋,ui=⌈x~i⌉l_i\coloneqq \lfloor \tilde{x}_i\rfloor, u_i = \lceil \tilde{x}_i\rceilli​:=⌊x~i​⌋,ui​=⌈x~i​⌉. Now x~∈{x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u}\tilde{x}\in \{x\in \mathbb{R}^n: Ax\ge b, l\le x\le u\}x~∈{x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u}. By the lemma, {x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u}\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\ge b, l\le x\le u\}{x∈Rn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u} is integral. Therefore,

x~∈conv({x∈Zn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u})⊆conv(P∩Zn)\tilde{x}\in \textrm{conv}(\{x\in \mathbb{Z}^n:Ax\ge b, l\le x\le u\})\subseteq \textrm{conv}(P\cap \mathbb{Z}^n) x~∈conv({x∈Zn:Ax≥b,l≤x≤u})⊆conv(P∩Zn)

Therefore P=conv(P∩Zn)P=\textrm{conv}(P\cap \mathbb{Z}^n)P=conv(P∩Zn), and PPP is integral. □\square□

Incidence Matrix Properties

Lemma (L16-6): let A∈{0,±1}m×nA\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times n}A∈{0,±1}m×n. If each column of AAA has at most one 111 and at most one −1-1−1, then AAA is totally unimodular.

Proof: suppose there exists A∈{0,±1}m×nA\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times n}A∈{0,±1}m×n satisfying the column condition and that AAA is not totally unimodular. We pick AAA to be the the minimal square submatrix (m=n)(m=n)(m=n) such that det⁡A≠{0,±1}\det A\neq \{0,\pm 1\}detA​={0,±1}. Since A∈{0,±1}m×m,m≥2A\in \{0,\pm 1\}^{m\times m}, m\ge 2A∈{0,±1}m×m,m≥2. Since we have a minimum counter example, each column has both a 111 and a −1-1−1. But then the rows of AAA sum to 0 (linearly dependent). Hence det⁡A=0\det A = 0detA=0, and we have a contradiction.

Recall incidence matrix of graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), the rows are VVV and the columns are EEE., for example:

Note that:

  1. The column-sums are all 2
  2. The row-sum for row v∈Vv\in Vv∈V is deg⁡(v)\deg(v)deg(v).
  3. AAA need not be TU\textrm{TU}TU

Theorem (L16-7): the incidence matrix of a bipartite graph is TU.

Proof: Let (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) be a bipartition of a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) and let AAA be the incidence matrix. Let A′A'A′ be obtained from AAA by multiplying the rows indexed by YYY by −1-1−1. By an earlier lemma, A′A'A′ is TU and hence AAA is TU. □\square□

Recall matching. M⊆E(G)M\subseteq E(G)M⊆E(G) is a matching if no two edges in MMM are incident with a common vertex. A matching MMM is perfect if each vertex is incident with an edge of MMM.

Matching Polyhedra: let AAA be the incidence matrix of a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E). Define

M(G)={x∈RE:Ax≤1,x≥0}PM(G)={x∈RE:Ax=1,x≥0}\begin{aligned} \textrm{M}(G) &= \{x\in \mathbb{R}^E:Ax\le 1, x\ge 0\}\\ \textrm{PM}(G) &= \{x\in \mathbb{R}^E:Ax = 1, x\ge 0\} \end{aligned} M(G)PM(G)​={x∈RE:Ax≤1,x≥0}={x∈RE:Ax=1,x≥0}​

For x∈REx\in \mathbb{R}^Ex∈RE, define support(x)={e∈E:xe≠0}\textrm{support}(x)= \{ e\in E : x_e\neq 0\}support(x)={e∈E:xe​​=0}. Note that

  1. M(G)∩ZE⊆{0,1}E\textrm{M}(G)\cap \mathbb{Z}^E\subseteq \{0,1\}^EM(G)∩ZE⊆{0,1}E
  2. For x∈{0,1}E,x∈M(G)⟺support(x)x\in \{0,1\}^E, x\in \textrm{M}(G) \Longleftrightarrow \textrm{support(x)}x∈{0,1}E,x∈M(G)⟺support(x) is a matching
  3. For x∈{0,1}E,x∈PM(G)⟺support(x)x\in \{0,1\}^E, x\in \textrm{PM}(G)\Longleftrightarrow \textrm{support(x)}x∈{0,1}E,x∈PM(G)⟺support(x) is a perfect matching.
  4. If GGG is bipartite, then AAA is TU and hence M(G)\textrm{M}(G)M(G) and PM(G)\textrm{PM}(G)PM(G) are integral.

Matching Polytope: let M(G)\mathcal{M}(G)M(G) denote the set of vectors x∈{0,1}Ex\in \{0,1\}^Ex∈{0,1}E such that support(x)\textrm{support}(x)support(x) is a matching, and let PM(G)\mathcal{PM}(G)PM(G) denote teh set of vectors x∈{0,1}Ex\in \{0,1\}^Ex∈{0,1}E such that support(x)\textrm{support}(x)support(x) is a perfect matching.

Theorem (L16-8): if GGG is a bipartite graph, then

conv(M(G))={x∈Rn:Ax≤1,x≥0}conv(PM(G))={x∈Rn:Ax=1,x≥0}\begin{aligned} \textrm{conv}(\mathcal{M}(G)) &=\{ x\in \mathbb{R}^n:Ax\le 1, x\ge 0 \}\\ \textrm{conv}(\mathcal{PM}(G)) &=\{x\in \mathbb{R}^n: Ax=1, x\ge 0\} \end{aligned}conv(M(G))conv(PM(G))​={x∈Rn:Ax≤1,x≥0}={x∈Rn:Ax=1,x≥0}​

Application Theorem (L16-9): for each r≥1r\ge 1r≥1, if GGG is an rrr-regular bipartite graph, then GGG has a perfect matching.

Proof: let x~=(1/r,…,1/r)\tilde{x}=(1/r,\dots,1/r)x~=(1/r,…,1/r). Hence Ax~=1A\tilde{x}=1Ax~=1 and x~≥0\tilde{x}\ge 0x~≥0. Then x~∈conv(PM(G))\tilde{x}\in \textrm{conv}(\mathcal{PM}(G))x~∈conv(PM(G)). Hence PM(G)≠ϕ\mathcal{PM}(G)\neq \phiPM(G)​=ϕ.□\square□
